cheatsheetvideos.quote: Alexa shares with us how she went in for her Class A permit and decided to get her Hazmat endorsement as a bonus!
Mark shares his feedback on his Class A CDL Cheat Sheet

questions.question: When transporting a load, the cargo should be inspected:
questions.answerA: Only at the beginning of a drive.
questions.answerB: Only after driving a long distance.
questions.answerC: After every break.
questions.explanation: Cargo and its securing devices must be inspected before starting a trip. After beginning a trip, the driver should check the load and securing devices within the first 50 miles on the road, every three hours or 150 miles traveled, and after every break.

questions.question: When using a fire extinguisher to put out a fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay as far away as possible from the flames.
questions.answerB: Aim at the flames.
questions.answerC: Use any extinguisher on every type of fire.
questions.explanation: Stay as far away from a fire as possible and aim your fire extinguisher at the source or base of the fire, not at the flames. It may be appropriate to extinguish certain fires with water. If you are unsure of how to treat a specific fire, you should wait for  trained firefighters to arrive.

questions.question: When in heavy traffic, the safest driving speed is:
questions.answerA: Slower than the speed being driven by surrounding traffic.
questions.answerB: The same speed being driven by surrounding traffic.
questions.answerC: Faster than the speed being driven by surrounding traffic.
questions.explanation: In heavy traffic, it is safest to travel at the same speed as other vehicles. If two vehicles continue to drive in the same direction at the same speed, they cannot hit each other.

questions.question: Blocking is used to:
questions.answerA: Prevent cargo from shifting.
questions.answerB: Prevent cargo from being loaded too high.
questions.answerC: Prevent cargo from being unloaded too quickly.
questions.explanation: Blocking is used in the front, in the back, and/or on the sides of a piece of cargo to keep it from sliding while the vehicle is in motion.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, you should:
questions.answerA: Place as little weight as possible over the axles.
questions.answerB: Place a well-balanced amount of weight over the axles.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with how the weight is distributed.
questions.explanation: A load of cargo must be properly balanced. Placing too much weight over an axle can damage the axle and make it more difficult for you to steer. Placing too little weight over an axle can cause poor traction, also leading to difficult handling.

questions.question: During the driving test, when asked to make a lane change:
questions.answerA: You should not be concerned with other motorists.
questions.answerB: You should use your turn signal and change lanes when safe.
questions.answerC: You should make the lane change as quickly as possible, even if that means cutting off another driver.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a lane change during the on-road driving test, you should make the proper traffic checks, use your turn signal, and smoothly change lanes when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Alcohol is removed from the body:
questions.answerA: By exercising.
questions.answerB: At a fixed rate.
questions.answerC: More quickly if the person stays awake.
questions.explanation: The liver removes alcohol from the body at a fixed rate. Despite popular belief, tricks like drinking coffee or taking a cold shower will not speed up the process. The only way to become sober is to allow your body the time it needs to remove the alcohol from your system.

questions.question: If a tire fails, you should:
questions.answerA: Use the brakes.
questions.answerB: Stay off the brakes.
questions.answerC: Swerve.
questions.explanation: Braking after a tire fails can result in a loss of control. Stay off your brakes, if possible, until your vehicle has slowed considerably.

questions.question: A second conviction of operating a CMV with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.04 percent will result in:
questions.answerA: The loss of your CDL for life.
questions.answerB: The loss of your CDL for five years.
questions.answerC: The loss of your CDL for one year.
questions.explanation: It is illegal to operate a CMV if your blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is 0.04 percent or higher. A first offense will result in the loss of your CDL for one year. A second offense will result in the loss of your CDL for life.

questions.question: When adjusting your mirrors before a trip:
questions.answerA: No part of your vehicle should be visible in any mirror.
questions.answerB: Part of your vehicle should be visible in the mirrors.
questions.answerC: More than half of each mirror should show the vehicle.
questions.explanation: When properly adjusted, your mirrors should each display some part of your vehicle. Being able to see your own vehicle in your mirrors will give you a point of reference when judging the positions of other objects.

questions.question: When drivers turn, they usually:
questions.answerA: Look in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: Look in the direction opposite the turn.
questions.answerC: Look behind their vehicles.
questions.explanation: When turning, drivers usually look in the direction of their turn. If a driver fails to signal before a turn or lane change, their body movements may still provide a clue that they are planning to turn.

questions.question: Broken suspension parts:
questions.answerA: Should be repaired immediately.
questions.answerB: Should be repaired, but not immediately.
questions.answerC: Cannot be identified.
questions.explanation: The suspension system performs the vital functions of holding up the vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Defects in the suspension are therefore extremely dangerous.

questions.question: When backing a truck, you should:
questions.answerA: Only use the side mirrors on the driver’s side.
questions.answerB: Use both side mirrors.
questions.answerC: Never use a helper.
questions.explanation: Backing a commercial motor vehicle is always dangerous because you cannot see everything behind you. When backing, make frequent checks of the mirrors on both sides of the vehicle. Use a helper whenever possible.

questions.question: To prevent becoming an aggressive driver you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Make gestures at other drivers.
questions.answerC: Give other drivers the benefit of the doubt.
questions.explanation: To avoid engaging in aggressive driving behavior, it is helpful to give other drivers the benefit of the doubt. Assume that they have valid reasons for what they are doing and don't take their actions personally.

questions.question: Items on a flatbed:
questions.answerA: Are usually heavy enough to not need to be strapped down.
questions.answerB: Should not be strapped down if you are driving more slowly than 35 mph.
questions.answerC: Must always be secured.
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers and trailers without sides, cargo must be tied down to prevent it from shifting or falling off in transit.

questions.question: While driving a vehicle, if an unusual noise or feeling occurs, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Assume it is not a concern and continue driving.
questions.answerB: Hope the vehicle makes it until it is switched to another driver.
questions.answerC: Check out the situation to determine the proper solutions.
questions.explanation: Use your senses during trips to help you identify mechanical issues. If you see, hear, smell, or feel anything that could indicate trouble, you should stop and check it out.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle is ____ in a minute.
questions.answerA: 2 psi
questions.answerB: 4 psi
questions.answerC: 6 psi
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A triple combination should have a leakage rate no higher than 6 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: People working on a disabled vehicle:
questions.answerA: Are probably aware of the roadway.
questions.answerB: May be distracted by the repair and not pay attention to the roadway.
questions.answerC: Are exempt from traffic laws.
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are working on a disabled vehicle on the side of the road. They may be focused on the repair and not paying attention to nearby traffic.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Air tanks are shared between both systems.
questions.answerB: Each system has its own air tanks.
questions.answerC: You must designate which system you are using.
questions.explanation: There are two air brake systems in a dual air brake system. The systems share a set of brake controls, but each system has its own tanks, hoses, and lines.

questions.question: Backing with a trailer is dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is difficult for the driver to see behind the trailer.
questions.answerB: There may be extra weight in the front of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Cargo may fall out of the trailer.
questions.answerD: Trailers are not made to be driven in reverse.
questions.explanation: Backing is always dangerous because it is impossible to see everything that is behind your vehicle. Only drive in reverse if it is absolutely necessary.

questions.question: If a vehicle begins to hydroplane, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Accelerate.
questions.answerB: Release the accelerator and push in the clutch.
questions.answerC: Pull in the clutch and brake.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, you can regain control by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch.

questions.question: When taking a driving test:
questions.answerA: You must supply the same type of vehicle for which you will require a CDL.
questions.answerB: You may supply any type of vehicle, even if it is not the type of vehicle for which you will be using with the CDL.
questions.answerC: The testing station will supply the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Skills tests must be taken in the type of vehicle the applicant plans to drive. The applicant is generally responsible to supply the testing vehicle.

questions.question: What eliminates alcohol from the bloodstream?
questions.answerA: Coffee
questions.answerB: Exercise
questions.answerC: Time
questions.explanation: The body processes alcohol at a fixed rate that cannot be sped up through tricks like drinking coffee. The only way to sober up is to give the body the time it needs to remove the alcohol on its own.

questions.question: If feeling tired while driving, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Take a pep pill.
questions.answerB: Get some rest.
questions.answerC: Continue driving.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel tired while driving, the only safe action to take is to stop and get some sleep. Trying to fight the fatigue and press on is very dangerous and can result in a fatal crash. You should not rely on artificial stimulants; these may help keep you awake a while longer, but they won't make you more alert.

questions.question: Placards should be used:
questions.answerA: Any time a vehicle is carrying hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: When there is extra space on a truck.
questions.answerC: Only when the amount of hazardous materials on a truck exceeds 200 pounds.
questions.explanation: Warning placards are required to be used any time a vehicle is carrying designated types and amounts of hazardous materials. A placarded vehicle must display placards on all four of its sides.

questions.question: What does blocking cargo do?
questions.answerA: Holds the cargo in a large box
questions.answerB: Prevents cargo from sliding in transit
questions.answerC: Prevent others from buying the cargo
questions.explanation: Blocking and bracing are used to prevent cargo from shifting in transit.

questions.question: What color light indicates a vehicle's ABS is not working?
questions.answerA: Green
questions.answerB: Blue
questions.answerC: Yellow
questions.explanation: On vehicles with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS), yellow malfunction lamps alert the driver to ABS malfunction.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerA: Can damage parts of a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Is necessary to warm up parts of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Is encouraged to improve a vehicle's gas mileage.
questions.explanation: Always speed up smoothly and gradually so that your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: What is the Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR)?
questions.answerA: The weight stated by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle
questions.answerB: The maximum weight that can be pulled by a vehicle
questions.answerC: The minimum weight that can be hauled by a vehicle
questions.explanation: A Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR) is the value specified by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle.

questions.question: To make your vehicle more visible during the day, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your low beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Use your high beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Use your clearance lights.
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights should be used for best visibility, even during the day. Using high beam headlights around other drivers can be dangerous.

questions.question: When it is difficult to see other vehicles, such as at dawn or dusk, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep your lights off.
questions.answerB: Turn your lights on.
questions.answerC: Drive on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: When driving at dawn, at dusk, or in inclement weather, you should use your headlights on their low beam setting to increase your visibility.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of tire failure?
questions.answerA: A loud sound
questions.answerB: Vibration
questions.answerC: Smoother steering
questions.explanation: If you experience tire failure, you may hear the loud "bang" sound of a blowout or feel a heavy thumping or vibration in your vehicle. If steering begins to feel heavy, or if the rear of your vehicle begins to fishtail, you should stop to check your tires.

questions.question: To determine if a vehicle can handle a load, you must know:
questions.answerA: The vehicle’s suspension rating.
questions.answerB: The tire rating for the front tires only.
questions.answerC: The tire rating for the rear tires only.
questions.explanation: It is a driver's responsibility to make sure their vehicle is not overloaded. They must be aware of legal weight limits and the maximum weight that their vehicle is rated to carry, including the weight capacity rating of the suspension system.

questions.question: If you are feeling tired and yawning a lot while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull over and take a nap.
questions.answerB: Get some coffee.
questions.answerC: Drive faster.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel tired while driving, you should stop to get some sleep. Trying to push on to reach your destination while tired is dangerous. You should not rely on caffeine to keep you awake.

questions.question: When checking your windshield wiper blades, the blades should be:
questions.answerA: Loose.
questions.answerB: Sticky.
questions.answerC: Secure.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check the wiper blades for damage, stiff rubber, and proper securement.

questions.question: In icy conditions, a retarder should be:
questions.answerA: Turned on.
questions.answerB: Turned off.
questions.answerC: Only used on the rear wheels.
questions.explanation: A retarder may cause a skid when traction is poor, such as when a road is icy, and should therefore be turned off in such conditions.

questions.question: If the coolant temperature gauge goes above the highest safe temperature, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue to drive.
questions.answerB: Pull over and figure out what's wrong.
questions.answerC: Run the air conditioner.
questions.explanation: If the coolant temperature gauge goes above the highest safe temperature, you should stop driving as soon as possible and try to figure out what is wrong. There could be an issue in your vehicle that could lead to engine failure and possibly a fire.

questions.question: Rolling backward when beginning to accelerate is dangerous because:
questions.answerA: The transmission may be damaged.
questions.answerB: The truck is not made to go backwards.
questions.answerC: You may hit a vehicle behind you.
questions.explanation: Be sure that you are able to accelerate without first rolling back. Rolling backwards may cause you to collide with a vehicle or other obstacle behind your truck.

questions.question: The parking brake in a newer vehicle is applied by:
questions.answerA: Moving a lever to the right.
questions.answerB: Pushing a yellow, diamond-shaped knob.
questions.answerC: Pulling a yellow, diamond-shaped knob.
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a yellow, diamond-shaped knob. The driver should pull the knob outward to apply the parking brakes and push the knob inward to release them.

questions.question: If you are convicted of a traffic violation:
questions.answerA: The State will inform your employer.
questions.answerB: You must tell your employer.
questions.answerC: You must tell the shipper.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any kind of traffic violation, in any type of vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days. You must also inform your motor vehicle licensing agency of the violation within 30 days if the conviction happened in another jurisdiction. This rule does not apply to parking infractions.

questions.question: Containerized loads are used:
questions.answerA: When the cargo is too large to fit on a truck.
questions.answerB: When the cargo has been or will be transported by a train.
questions.answerC: When the cargo is a liquid.
questions.explanation: Containerized loads are generally used when freight is carried partway by rail or ship. Sealed materials cannot be inspected, but a driver should ensure that the containers do not exceed safe and legal weight limits.

questions.question: If you are braking on dry pavement while traveling at 55 mph, how much distance will brake lag add to your overall stopping distance?
questions.answerA: 32 feet
questions.answerB: 45 feet
questions.answerC: 20 feet
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to the vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: If convicted of a traffic violation, you must inform your employer:
questions.answerA: Within three hours.
questions.answerB: Within a week.
questions.answerC: Within 30 days.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any kind of traffic violation in any type of vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days of the incident. You must also inform your motor vehicle licensing agency within 30 days if the incident happened in another jurisdiction. This rule does not apply to parking infractions.

questions.question: Blocking is used to:
questions.answerA: Keep cargo in a large box.
questions.answerB: Prevent cargo from sliding in a trailer.
questions.answerC: Prevent cargo from falling out of a trailer.
questions.explanation: Blocking may be used on all sides of a piece of cargo to keep it from sliding while the vehicle is in motion.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact to better communicate with them.
questions.answerB: Ignore their gestures.
questions.answerC: Not move out of their path of travel.
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, it is most important to get out of their way, if possible. Do not make eye contact with the driver, as doing so could provoke them. Do not let them provoke you with their actions.

questions.question: Before beginning to drive downhill, you should:
questions.answerA: Take your vehicle out of gear.
questions.answerB: Shift into a lower gear.
questions.answerC: Move into the left lane.
questions.explanation: To avoid overusing your brakes, you should always shift into a lower gear before starting down a hill.

questions.question: When making a left turn where there are two available turn lanes, a driver should begin the turn in the rightmost lane because:
questions.answerA: It will be easier for the driver to keep track of turning vehicles on their left than on their right.
questions.answerB: The vehicle will be able to turn more quickly.
questions.answerC: Other vehicles will get out of the turning vehicle's way.
questions.explanation: If making a left turn where there is more than one available turn lane, you should always choose to begin your turn in the rightmost lane. Large vehicles often have to swing right to make left turns. Because of this, it is safer for you to have other left-turning traffic to your left instead of to your right. This will allow you to have the best possible view of other turning vehicles and will lower the risk of your vehicle colliding with them.

questions.question: Strong winds usually cause the greatest issues for:
questions.answerA: Lighter vehicles.
questions.answerB: Heavier vehicles.
questions.answerC: Flatbed trailers.
questions.explanation: Strong winds can make it difficult for a driver to maintain control of their vehicle. Usually, this is especially true for drivers of lighter CMVs.

questions.question: Once they have begun to drive after a tire on their vehicle has been changed, a driver should stop after a short distance to:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the lug nuts are still tight.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the tire is wearing evenly.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the air pressure of the tire is still acceptable.
questions.explanation: Once you have begun to drive after a tire has been changed, you should stop after a short distance to recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.

questions.question: A liver can process about ____ per hour.
questions.answerA: One alcoholic drink
questions.answerB: Two alcoholic drinks
questions.answerC: Three alcoholic drinks
questions.explanation: The faster you drink, the higher your blood alcohol content (BAC) will become. The liver removes alcohol from a body at a fixed rate of about one drink per hour.

questions.question: You should specifically look out for black ice:
questions.answerA: When it is snowing.
questions.answerB: When the temperature is below freezing and the road looks wet.
questions.answerC: When the temperature is above freezing and there is snow on the ground.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. Be alert to black ice any time the temperature is below freezing and the road surface looks wet.

questions.question: If your vehicle is hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerA: Accelerate.
questions.answerB: Not use the brakes.
questions.answerC: Put the vehicle in reverse.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, do not apply the brakes. Instead, slow down by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch. This will help you to regain traction.

questions.question: Applicants seeking a hazardous materials endorsement must pass a threat assessment through which agency?
questions.answerA: The TSA
questions.answerB: The FBI
questions.answerC: The CIA
questions.explanation: Applicants seeking a hazardous materials endorsement must undergo a threat assessment conducted by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).

questions.question: When turning, you should:
questions.answerA: Signal before the turn.
questions.answerB: Turn off your turn signal just before starting the turn.
questions.answerC: Signal only if vehicles are in front of you.
questions.explanation: Be sure to activate the appropriate turn signal well in advance of a turn or lane change. Signal continuously throughout the turn and make sure to cancel the signal after the turn is completed, if your vehicle doesn't have self-canceling signals.

questions.question: If exiting a bus, a driver must:
questions.answerA: Never make contact with the handrail.
questions.answerB: Maintain contact with the handrail.
questions.answerC: Move quickly.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.

questions.question: Hanging meat:
questions.answerA: Should never be transported by trailer.
questions.answerB: Can be an unstable load.
questions.answerC: Must be approved by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).
questions.explanation: An operator should drive with care when transporting a cargo of hanging meat. Such a load is unstable, both because it has a high center of gravity and because the swinging of the meat can affect the driver's handling of the vehicle.

questions.question: An after-trip inspection should be done:
questions.answerA: Once a week.
questions.answerB: Once a month.
questions.answerC: After every trip.
questions.explanation: You should always complete an after-trip inspection of your vehicle at the end of a trip, day, or tour of duty. Complete a vehicle inspection report, if required.

questions.question: Broken suspension parts:
questions.answerA: Should be repaired immediately.
questions.answerB: Should be repaired, but not immediately.
questions.answerC: Cannot be identified.
questions.explanation: The suspension system performs the vital functions of holding up the vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Defects in the suspension are therefore extremely dangerous.

questions.question: Friction in an S-cam brake is caused when the brake shoes and linings:
questions.answerA: Press against the outside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Press against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.answerC: Push against each other.
questions.explanation: Friction inside a brake drum is caused when the brake shoes and linings push against the inside of the drum. The friction in the drums will slow and stop the vehicle.

questions.question: The Individual Vehicle Distance Record (IVDR) does not need to include which of the following?
questions.answerA: Trip origin
questions.answerB: Vehicle Identification Number
questions.answerC: Number of meals eaten by the driver
questions.explanation: An Individual Vehicle Distance Record (IVDR) must include information about the distance traveled by a vehicle and the amount of fuel purchased. The required distance information includes the origin and destination points of the trip and the Vehicle Identification Number.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, weight should be:
questions.answerA: Placed as high as possible.
questions.answerB: Placed as low as possible.
questions.answerC: Placed as far to the left as possible.
questions.explanation: Cargo with a high center of gravity makes a vehicle more likely to tip over than cargo with a low center of gravity. For this reason, it is important that the weight of cargo be distributed as low as possible.

questions.question: Cargo should be covered:
questions.answerA: To protect people from spillage.
questions.answerB: To hide the materials.
questions.answerC: To make it more difficult to steal.
questions.explanation: You should cover your cargo to protect people from the cargo if it spills, as well as to protect the cargo from the weather.

questions.question: When pulled off on the side of the road:
questions.answerA: A driver should keep the driver’s side door open.
questions.answerB: A driver should turn on the emergency flashers.
questions.answerC: The driver should wave their arms.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, make sure to use your four-way emergency flashers. This is particularly important at night.

questions.question: If you are turning left at an intersection where there are two available turn lanes:
questions.answerA: It is best to use the right lane.
questions.answerB: It doesn’t matter which lane you use.
questions.answerC: It is best to use the left lane.
questions.explanation: You may have to swing right to safely make a left turn. If there are two left turn lanes available at an intersection, you should always begin your turn in the rightmost lane.

questions.question: During the driving test, when encountering a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass another vehicle on the tracks if the other vehicle is going too slow.
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle to check for a train.
questions.answerC: Not change gears while your vehicle is on the tracks.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, do not stop, change gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in a railroad crossing.

questions.question: Why should the steps of a pre-trip inspection be done in the same order each time?
questions.answerA: Because you will be less likely to forget to check something
questions.answerB: Because it will be faster
questions.answerC: Because it is required by law
questions.explanation: Pre-trip inspections should be conducted in the same way every time. This will reinforce the steps, making it less likely that you will forget to inspect something important.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, the heaviest cargo should be placed:
questions.answerA: On top of the lightest parts of the cargo.
questions.answerB: Under the lightest parts of the cargo.
questions.answerC: At the rear of the trailer.
questions.explanation: It is important that vehicles are not top-heavy, if at all possible. A top-heavy vehicle is at an increased risk of rollover. Place the heaviest pieces of cargo underneath lighter pieces of cargo.

questions.question: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on in a vehicle with air brakes, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Test the brakes while driving, but continue driving if nothing seems wrong.
questions.answerB: Immediately stop driving.
questions.answerC: Drive with the hazard lights activated.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on while you are operating a vehicle with air brakes, you should stop and safely park the vehicle as soon as possible. It is essential that you are able to stop safely while you still have some braking power remaining.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, you should begin by:
questions.answerA: Turning the steering wheel in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: Turning the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.answerC: Turning the wheel as sharply as possible.
questions.explanation: When backing with a trailer, begin by turning the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the turn. Once the trailer starts to turn, reverse the direction of the steering wheel to follow the trailer.

questions.question: For a hazardous materials endorsement, an applicant will be required to:
questions.answerA: Provide their fingerprints and undergo a background check.
questions.answerB: Provide employment history from the last five years.
questions.answerC: Provide a list of countries visited within the last 10 years.
questions.explanation: To obtain a hazardous materials endorsement, you must submit your fingerprints and pass a background check.

questions.question: If your brakes fail when traveling downhill, decide what to do as quickly as possible because:
questions.answerA: The longer you wait, the faster your vehicle will go.
questions.answerB: The longer you wait, the more vehicles will get out of your way.
questions.answerC: The longer you wait, the slower your vehicle will go.
questions.explanation: However you choose to deal with a brake failure on a downhill slope, it is important that you make your decision as quickly as possible. The longer you wait to act, the faster your vehicle will be moving, and the harder it will become to stop.

questions.question: When it is difficult to see and you are traveling near other drivers, you should:
questions.answerA: Use high beam lights.
questions.answerB: Use low beam lights.
questions.answerC: Use only the clearance lights.
questions.explanation: Use your low beam headlights when traveling near other drivers at times when it is difficult to see, such as at dawn, at dusk, or in poor weather conditions. Using the high beam setting under certain conditions could make it difficult for other drivers to see.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Air tanks are shared between both systems.
questions.answerB: Each system has its own air tanks.
questions.answerC: You must designate which system you are using.
questions.explanation: There are two air brake systems in a dual air brake system. The systems share a set of brake controls, but each system has its own tanks, hoses, and lines.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerA: Is not a concern.
questions.answerB: Only occurs as a result of people who are physically doing something while driving.
questions.answerC: Can occur as a result of mental activities, such as daydreaming.
questions.explanation: Distractions while driving can be physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as making conversation with a passenger), or both (such as holding a phone to send texts). Strategies to help you avoid distracted driving include pre-programming radio stations; planning out your route in advance; avoiding complex or emotionally taxing conversation while driving; adjusting your mirrors before setting out; and not eating, drinking, or smoking while behind the wheel.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle controls skills test exercise, your vehicle's final position should be:
questions.answerA: In the general area that was described by the examiner.
questions.answerB: In the exact final position described by the examiner.
questions.answerC: Within three feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.explanation: You should finish each exercise with your vehicle in the exact position described by the examiner. You can be penalized for failing to complete an exercise exactly in the manner described by the examiner, potentially resulting in failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: Alcohol can be removed from your system:
questions.answerA: By exercising.
questions.answerB: By drinking coffee.
questions.answerC: By waiting.
questions.explanation: The liver removes alcohol from the body at a fixed rate, so the only way to sober up after consuming alcohol is to allow your body time to remove the alcohol on its own.

questions.question: Using an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: Is required in some states.
questions.answerB: Shortens brake response time.
questions.answerC: Provides additional control.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps to provide additional control during hard braking, but does not necessarily shorten a vehicle's stopping distance.

questions.question: If unable to tell if the road is becoming icy and slippery, a driver:
questions.answerA: Should try guessing.
questions.answerB: May open their window and feel the front of the side mirror for ice.
questions.answerC: Should look at the road closely.
questions.explanation: If you think the road surface may be becoming icy but you are not certain, you can open your window and feel the front of the side mirror, mirror support, or antenna. If ice has formed on any of these items, the road is likely becoming icy as well.

questions.question: Driving at night is usually:
questions.answerA: More difficult than driving during the day.
questions.answerB: Simpler than driving during the day.
questions.answerC: Discouraged.
questions.explanation: There are several reasons why driving at night is more difficult than driving during the day. It is more difficult for drivers to see hazards, the glare of headlights can affect drivers' vision, and there are more fatigued drivers on the road.

questions.question: An air compressor governor controls:
questions.answerA: When the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: How fast air is pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: The temperature of the air pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: Regrooved tires:
questions.answerA: Should not be used on any vehicle.
questions.answerB: Should not be used on the front of a bus.
questions.answerC: Should not be used on trucks hauling gravel.
questions.explanation: Regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires are prohibited on the front wheels of a bus.

questions.question: Unsafely reaching for a phone is:
questions.answerA: Acceptable if you are driving without a passenger.
questions.answerB: Acceptable if you plan to use a hands-free feature.
questions.answerC: Unacceptable even if you plan to use a hands-free feature.
questions.explanation: If you must use a mobile phone while driving, it must be in close proximity to you and easily reachable while you are securely fastened into your seat. It is dangerous and non-compliant to unsafely reach for a mobile phone, even if you plan to use a hands-free feature when speaking on the phone.

questions.question: When approaching your vehicle as part of your pre-trip inspection, you should look for what as a sign of trouble?
questions.answerA: A puddle of oil under the vehicle
questions.answerB: Inflated tires
questions.answerC: Lug nuts that look tight
questions.explanation: When approaching your vehicle for an inspection, you should look underneath the vehicle for fresh leaks of oil, coolant, grease, or fuel. Seeing a fresh puddle of any of these fluids could indicate a safety issue with your vehicle.

questions.question: Foundation brakes are used:
questions.answerA: Only on the front wheels of a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Only on the rear wheels of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: On each wheel of a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Foundation brakes are used on each wheel of a CMV. The most common type of foundation brake is the s-cam drum brake.

questions.question: When stopping, the brake pedal should be:
questions.answerA: Pressed down gradually.
questions.answerB: Pressed down quickly.
questions.answerC: Pressed down repeatedly, but not held down continuously.
questions.explanation: When stopping, it is best to gradually press down the brake pedal.

questions.question: What is reaction distance?
questions.answerA: The distance you will travel between realizing you must brake and when you physically hit the brakes
questions.answerB: The distance you will travel between a hazard becoming visible and you seeing the hazard
questions.answerC: The distance you will travel between seeing a hazard and realizing you must brake
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's stopping distance can be calculated by adding together your perception distance, your reaction distance, and your vehicle's braking distance. Reaction distance is the distance traveled between the moment you mentally perceive a hazard and the moment you physically hit the brakes.

questions.question: Some air brake systems introduce alcohol into the system to:
questions.answerA: Make the brakes work without squeaking.
questions.answerB: Prevent ice from forming in the brake system.
questions.answerC: Prevent people from breathing the air from the system.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems contain an alcohol evaporator. An evaporator introduces alcohol into the system to help inhibit the formation of ice in cold weather.

questions.question: If you have an engine fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Open the hood as soon as possible.
questions.answerB: Turn off the engine as soon as possible.
questions.answerC: Not use a fire extinguisher.
questions.explanation: To keep an engine fire from spreading, you should turn off the vehicle's engine as soon as possible. Do not open the hood if you don't have to.

questions.question: Of the following, which is the most slippery surface?
questions.answerA: Ice that is dry
questions.answerB: Ice that is wet
questions.answerC: Wet pavement
questions.explanation: Ice becomes wet when the weather is just warm enough to melt the ice slightly. Wet ice is much more slippery than ice that is not wet.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection should include:
questions.answerA: A check of the engine oil level.
questions.answerB: Removing coolant.
questions.answerC: Washing the tire rims.
questions.explanation: When examining the engine compartment during a pre-trip inspection, you should check the engine oil level, the radiator coolant level, and the condition of the hoses.

questions.question: If the safety relief valve in the air brake system releases air:
questions.answerA: The compressor needs more air.
questions.answerB: The air pressure has become too high.
questions.answerC: The brakes are fully operational.
questions.explanation: An air brake system has a safety relief valve, which releases air from the tanks if the pressure gets too high. If the valve must operate, something in the system is wrong and should be addressed by a mechanic.

questions.question: Steering wheel play should be no more than:
questions.answerA: 10 degrees.
questions.answerB: 50 degrees.
questions.answerC: 75 degrees.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should have no more than 10 degrees of play. This is equal to about two inches of movement at the rim of a 20-inch wheel. If there is more play than this, it may be difficult to steer.

questions.question: Emergency equipment, such as fire extinguishers, are:
questions.answerA: Only needed in vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Only needed for interstate travel.
questions.answerC: Required in all commercial motor vehicles.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles must carry appropriate emergency equipment, including fire extinguishers.

questions.question: When driving a truck requiring a CDL:
questions.answerA: You do not need to wear a seat belt.
questions.answerB: You are required to wear a seat belt, but only if transporting more than 500 pounds of cargo.
questions.answerC: You must always wear a seat belt.
questions.explanation: You must be properly restrained by a safety belt at all times when driving a commercial motor vehicle.

questions.question: Poisonous fumes can enter a cab due to:
questions.answerA: A defective exhaust system.
questions.answerB: Using the wrong type of fuel.
questions.answerC: A lack of oil in the engine.
questions.explanation: A faulty exhaust system is a serious safety hazard. It may allow poisonous fumes to enter the vehicle's cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: Placards should be used:
questions.answerA: Any time a vehicle is carrying hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: When there is extra space on a truck.
questions.answerC: Only when the amount of hazardous materials on a truck exceeds 200 pounds.
questions.explanation: Warning placards are required to be used any time a vehicle is carrying designated types and amounts of hazardous materials. A placarded vehicle must display placards on all four of its sides.

questions.question: Why do large vehicles use air brakes?
questions.answerA: Other brake systems squeak too loudly.
questions.answerB: Air brakes are very effective systems.
questions.answerC: Other braking systems are hard to come by.
questions.explanation: If used and maintained properly, air brakes are a safe and effective way to stop large, heavy vehicles.

questions.question: When conducting a pre-drive inspection:
questions.answerA: The inspection report is not important.
questions.answerB: The inspection report must only be reviewed if there will be passengers in the vehicle.
questions.answerC: The previous inspection report should be reviewed, if applicable.
questions.explanation: The first step of a vehicle inspection is to review the last vehicle inspection report. Only sign the report if noted defects are certified to have been repaired.

questions.question: The leading factor resulting in death and injury in work zones is:
questions.answerA: Speeding.
questions.answerB: Stopping.
questions.answerC: Under-inflated tires.
questions.explanation: The leading cause of injury and death in roadway work zones is excessive speed by passing drivers. Lower your speed when driving through a work zone.

questions.question: After a vehicle is started, warning lights and buzzers:
questions.answerA: Should stay on for several minutes.
questions.answerB: Should turn off within a few seconds.
questions.answerC: Should stay on until manually turned off.
questions.explanation: After a vehicle is started, the warning lights and buzzers should go out after a few seconds. If the warning signals do not turn off, there may be something wrong with the vehicle.

questions.question: Water that has collected on a roadway can cause:
questions.answerA: Hydroplaning.
questions.answerB: Acceleration.
questions.answerC: Stopping.
questions.explanation: The risk of hydroplaning begins when water has collected on the surface of a road.

questions.question: If you notice anything affecting the safety or mechanical functioning of your CMV while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay quiet and see if the problem goes away.
questions.answerB: Make a written report that includes your concerns.
questions.answerC: Try to fix it yourself.
questions.explanation: At the end of each day of driving, you may be required to make a written report on the vehicle or vehicles driven. Be sure to make note of any issues that could affect the safety of the vehicle or that could lead to a mechanical breakdown.

questions.question: While driving, gauges are:
questions.answerA: Unreliable.
questions.answerB: Unpredictable.
questions.answerC: To be monitored for potential signs of trouble.
questions.explanation: While driving, you should watch your vehicle's gauges for signs of trouble. Be sure to inspect your gauges before beginning a trip to ensure that they are in proper working order.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerA: Change a tire.
questions.answerB: Explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why.
questions.answerC: Estimate the weight of a load on a trailer.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. You will need to explain what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: What is the Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR)?
questions.answerA: The weight stated by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle
questions.answerB: The maximum weight that can be pulled by a vehicle
questions.answerC: The minimum weight that can be hauled by a vehicle
questions.explanation: A Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR) is the value specified by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Should not be used in cold weather.
questions.answerB: Are helpful to remove water and oil from the air tanks.
questions.answerC: Are used to move air to the brakes.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually has a certain amount of water and oil in it. This can harm the system if allowed to accumulate. Air tanks have drain valves to aid in removing water and oil from the compressed air.

questions.question: If your brakes fail while you are traveling downhill and there is no available escape ramp, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep pumping the brakes.
questions.answerB: Turn the vehicle off.
questions.answerC: Drive into an open field.
questions.explanation: If your brakes fail while you are driving downhill, you should first look for an escape ramp to stop your vehicle. If no ramp is available, you should look for an alternative place to bring your vehicle to a stop, such as an open field or side road that flattens out or turns uphill.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of bad brakes?
questions.answerA: Cracked drums
questions.answerB: Very thin pads
questions.answerC: Pads free of oil or grease
questions.explanation: When inspecting your brakes, you should check for cracked drums; shoes or pads covered in oil, grease, or brake fluid; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: If you must drive in reverse, using driver's side backing:
questions.answerA: Is always encouraged.
questions.answerB: Is discouraged.
questions.answerC: Is only recommended if it is raining.
questions.explanation: If you must back up, it is safest to back toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This way, as the driver, you will have the best possible view of your path of travel.

questions.question: If involved in an accident, which of the following is not recommended?
questions.answerA: Trying to move your vehicle to the side of the road
questions.answerB: Caring for the injured
questions.answerC: Driving away from the scene
questions.explanation: When involved in an accident, you should protect the area, notify authorities, care for the injured, collect required information, and report the accident. You can lose your license for leaving the scene of an accident.

questions.question: Vehicles driving behind a truck:
questions.answerA: May have difficulty seeing objects in front of the truck.
questions.answerB: Often have a great view of the roadway in front of them.
questions.answerC: Do not need to signal.
questions.explanation: Your truck may block the views of drivers behind you, making them unaware of any upcoming hazards that require you to stop. For this reason, it is a good idea to flash your brakes and warn other drivers before slowing or stopping.

questions.question: What is a retarder?
questions.answerA: A device that prevents a vehicle from going too fast
questions.answerB: A device that prevents a vehicle from being too loud
questions.answerC: A device that improves a vehicle's gas mileage
questions.explanation: Retarders help to slow vehicles, reducing drivers' need to use brakes.

questions.question: If backing a truck:
questions.answerA: You should rely on your mirrors to guide you.
questions.answerB: You should first walk the area to become more familiar with obstacles.
questions.answerC: You should look straight ahead.
questions.explanation: If you must drive in reverse, you should first walk around your vehicle to look at the path of travel and check for obstacles. Because mirrors have blind spots, you cannot rely exclusively on them. It is recommended to use a helper whenever possible.

questions.question: While driving a vehicle, if an unusual noise or feeling occurs, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Assume it is not a concern and continue driving.
questions.answerB: Hope the vehicle makes it until it is switched to another driver.
questions.answerC: Check out the situation to determine the proper solutions.
questions.explanation: Use your senses during trips to help you identify mechanical issues. If you see, hear, smell, or feel anything that could indicate trouble, you should stop and check it out.

questions.question: Once they have begun to drive after a tire on their vehicle has been changed, a driver should stop after a short distance to:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the lug nuts are still tight.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the tire is wearing evenly.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the air pressure of the tire is still acceptable.
questions.explanation: Once you have begun to drive after a tire has been changed, you should stop after a short distance to recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.

questions.question: Pre-trip inspections should be done:
questions.answerA: Differently each time in order to place emphasis on different items.
questions.answerB: The same way each time to prevent you from forgetting anything.
questions.answerC: Once in a while.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip inspection should be completed in the same way before every drive. Consistency will help you learn all of the proper steps and decrease the likelihood that you will forget to check something.

questions.question: When driving in hot weather:
questions.answerA: The air pressure in tires will decrease.
questions.answerB: The engine oil can help to keep the engine cool.
questions.answerC: Antifreeze is not important.
questions.explanation: Because air pressure increases as air expands in the heat, it is important to monitor your tire pressure when driving in very hot weather. To prevent the engine from overheating, there must be an adequate amount of oil in the engine, as well as enough water and antifreeze in the cooling system. Antifreeze is helpful for the engine in both hot and cold weather.

questions.question: When driving in winter, which of the following should receive extra attention in a pre-trip inspection?
questions.answerA: Coolant and antifreeze levels
questions.answerB: The air conditioning unit
questions.answerC: The oil pressure
questions.explanation: When doing a pre-trip inspection during the winter, you should pay extra attention to the coolant level and amount of antifreeze; the defrosting and heating equipment; the wiper blades and windshield washer; the tires and tire chains; the lights and reflectors; the windows and mirrors; the hand holds, steps, and deck plates; the radiator shuttles and winterfront; and exhaust system.

questions.question: A danger of swerving to avoid a hazard while driving a large truck is that:
questions.answerA: The truck may miss the object.
questions.answerB: The truck may flip over.
questions.answerC: The truck may stay in the same lane.
questions.explanation: While swerving can sometimes be the safest way to handle a hazard on the roadway, doing so is not without risk. Top-heavy vehicles and tractors with multiple trailers may flip over in a swerve.

questions.question: What is a tire load?
questions.answerA: The minimum safe weight a tire can carry
questions.answerB: The maximum safe weight a tire can carry
questions.answerC: The weight of a tire
questions.explanation: Tire load is defined as the maximum safe weight that a tire can carry at a specified pressure.

questions.question: If brakes fail on a long downgrade, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Turn the vehicle off and then back on to reset the brakes.
questions.answerB: Pump the brakes.
questions.answerC: Look for an escape ramp or other way to stop.
questions.explanation: If your brakes fail on a downgrade, your best option is to use an escape ramp. If no escape ramp is available, it is a good idea to look for a different escape route, such as a side road or open field.

questions.question: A steering wheel should be:
questions.answerA: Held with one hand while the other hand rests.
questions.answerB: Held with both hands to ensure an adequate grip.
questions.answerC: Released if the vehicle is approaching a bump.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should be held firmly with each hand on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indicator of when to change gears?
questions.answerA: Engine speed (rpm)
questions.answerB: Road speed (mph)
questions.answerC: The speed of the vehicle next to you
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: What do the two systems of a dual air brake system share?
questions.answerA: Hoses
questions.answerB: An air compressor
questions.answerC: Air tanks
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: Too much air pressure in a tire:
questions.answerA: Is not possible.
questions.answerB: Is encouraged on long drives.
questions.answerC: Can be dangerous.
questions.explanation: Tires should never have too much air pressure. Be sure to check your tires' air pressure with a gauge during inspections.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, turning toward the driver’s side is encouraged:
questions.answerA: Because it allows the driver a better view.
questions.answerB: Because turning toward the passenger side is illegal.
questions.answerC: Because other drivers can offer assistance.
questions.explanation: If you must back up, it is safest to back toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This way, as the driver, you will have the best possible view of your path of travel.

questions.question: If driving so slowly that you could impede other drivers, you should:
questions.answerA: Drive in the left lane.
questions.answerB: Drive while using your four-way flashers.
questions.answerC: Drive without using any lights.
questions.explanation: If you must drive so slowly that you will impede the flow of traffic, you should turn on your four-way flashers to alert drivers behind you (as long as local laws allow the use of flashers).

questions.question: To make a stop in a vehicle equipped with air brakes, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Press the brake pedal down.
questions.answerB: Lift the brake pedal up.
questions.answerC: Pull out the air brake knob.
questions.explanation: To make a normal stop in a vehicle that is equipped with air brakes, you should simply press the brake pedal down.

questions.question: Your horn should be used to:
questions.answerA: Tell other drivers that you are angry.
questions.answerB: Warn other drivers that you are near.
questions.answerC: Frighten other drivers.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's horn is a tool to warn others of your presence. Because the horn may create danger by startling other drivers, you should use it only if necessary.

questions.question: You should always be able to stop within:
questions.answerA: 10 feet of your vehicle.
questions.answerB: 100 feet of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Your view of the road ahead.
questions.explanation: It is essential that your vehicle will be able to stop within the area of the road that you are able to see. This means that you must slow down whenever conditions reduce visibility.

questions.question: When loading cargo, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Stack items as high as possible.
questions.answerB: Know the weight capacity rating of the suspension system.
questions.answerC: Place light items underneath heavier items.
questions.explanation: It is a driver's responsibility to make sure their vehicle is not overloaded. They must be aware of legal weight limits and the maximum weight that their vehicle is rated to carry, including the weight capacity rating of the suspension system.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the ____ come on automatically when air pressure falls below 45 psi.
questions.answerA: Spring brakes
questions.answerB: Parking brakes
questions.answerC: Air brakes
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when air tank pressure falls to a level between 20 and 45 psi. You can do this by chocking the wheels and releasing air from the braking system by stepping on and off the brake pedal. Once the pressure levels drop to an unsafe level, the parking brake valve should pop out and spring brakes should come on.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.answerA: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS).
questions.answerB: Bluetooth.
questions.answerC: A GPS.
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997, and other vehicles with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1998, must be equipped with anti-lock brakes.

questions.question: If driving through flowing water or a large puddle, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Gently apply the brakes.
questions.answerC: Try to stop in the water.
questions.explanation: It is best to avoid driving through large puddles or moving water. If there is no way to avoid driving through water, you should slow down, shift into a low gear, and gently apply the brakes. Pressing linings against the brake drums or discs will keep water, mud, silt, and sand from getting inside the brake mechanisms.

questions.question: To avoid a hazard:
questions.answerA: You should always steer to the left.
questions.answerB: You may be able to drive onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: You should steer sharply in one direction.
questions.explanation: In some emergencies, the best strategy for avoiding a hazard may be to drive onto the shoulder. Most shoulders are strong enough to support the weight of a large vehicle.

questions.question: When stopping in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Veer your trailer to the right and stop.
questions.answerB: Stop in a straight line.
questions.answerC: Veer your trailer to the left and stop.
questions.explanation: If you need to make an emergency stop, you can use either the controlled braking method or the stab braking method. It's important to brake in a way that keeps your vehicle in a straight line but will still allow you to turn if necessary.

questions.question: Loading cargo improperly:
questions.answerA: Improves fuel efficiency.
questions.answerB: Can be dangerous.
questions.answerC: Usually makes unloading easier.
questions.explanation: Proper loading and securement of cargo is essential for safety. Improperly loaded cargo could damage a vehicle, as well as cause injury or death by falling off in a collision or sudden stop.

questions.question: A cracked rim should be:
questions.answerA: Repaired by welding.
questions.answerB: Relocated to one of a pair of dual tires.
questions.answerC: Replaced.
questions.explanation: A driver should inspect wheels before a drive, specifically looking for damage on the wheels and rims. Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use.

questions.question: Texting while driving is especially dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is both a mental and physical distraction.
questions.answerB: A message may be upsetting to the driver.
questions.answerC: People like to read and may become too engaged in their phones.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is particularly dangerous because it is both a mental and physical distraction to the driver. In addition to diverting a driver's mental attention away from the road, texting requires a person to remove at least one hand from the vehicle's controls.

questions.question: Cargo being transported should be checked:
questions.answerA: Only before the trip.
questions.answerB: Before the trip and again within the first 50 miles of the trip.
questions.answerC: Only by the loading personnel.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be inspected before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of the trip, and every three hours or 150 miles traveled thereafter. Cargo should be inspected every time the driver stops to take a break. The driver of a truck transporting cargo is responsible for the cargo being safely secured throughout the trip.

questions.question: ABS brakes:
questions.answerA: Help you avoid wheel lockup.
questions.answerB: Lock up your vehicle's wheels.
questions.answerC: Prevent your vehicle from accelerating when going uphill.
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up when the driver brakes hard on a slippery surface.

questions.question: A vehicle that is smaller than your vehicle:
questions.answerA: Will usually be able to stop faster than your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Will usually take more time to stop than your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Will take about the same amount of time to stop as your vehicle.
questions.explanation: In general, a smaller vehicle will be able to come to a complete stop faster than a larger vehicle. Keep this in mind when determining your following distance.

questions.question: In icy conditions, a retarder should be:
questions.answerA: Turned on.
questions.answerB: Turned off.
questions.answerC: Only used on the rear wheels.
questions.explanation: A retarder may cause a skid when traction is poor, such as when a road is icy, and should therefore be turned off in such conditions.

questions.question: In order to receive a hazardous materials endorsement, a person must complete all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: A HazMat knowledge test.
questions.answerB: An FBI fingerprint check.
questions.answerC: A CIA intelligence check.
questions.explanation: To obtain a hazardous materials endorsement, you must pass the HazMat knowledge test; undergo a Federal Security Threat Assessment; provide proof of U.S. citizenship or permanent residency; and undergo an FBI fingerprint check and federal criminal history background check.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, belts should be:
questions.answerA: Left alone and not inspected.
questions.answerB: Checked for tightness.
questions.answerC: Inspected, but only about once a month.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check all belts for tightness and excessive wear.

questions.question: When starting an engine as part of a pre-trip inspection, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Listen for unusual noises.
questions.answerB: Place the engine in first gear.
questions.answerC: Turn on the heater.
questions.explanation: Check your engine during the pre-trip inspection. After starting the engine, you should listen for unusual noises.

questions.question: If there is a cargo fire in a box trailer:
questions.answerA: The trailer doors should be opened.
questions.answerB: The trailer doors should not be opened.
questions.answerC: A large, heavy blanket should be put over the trailer.
questions.explanation: The doors of a trailer should be not be opened in the event of a cargo fire, especially if the cargo includes hazardous materials. Opening trailer doors would increase the fire's oxygen supply, potentially causing the fire to increase in size.

questions.question: Who is responsible for ensuring cargo is loaded properly?
questions.answerA: The driver
questions.answerB: The shipper
questions.answerC: The recipient
questions.explanation: A driver is responsible for four things related to transporting cargo. They are responsible for inspecting the cargo, recognizing overloads and poorly balanced weight, ensuring that the cargo is secured without obstructing their view, and ensuring that the cargo is not obstructing access to emergency equipment.

questions.question: When asked to make a turn while taking your driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your turn signal, but only if other cars are present.
questions.answerB: Check traffic only in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerC: Check traffic in all directions.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a turn during the on-road driving test, you must check traffic in all directions and use your turn signal.

questions.question: Having weight loaded in a way that creates a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Increases the likelihood of a rollover.
questions.answerB: Increases the likelihood that items will fall down.
questions.answerC: Increases the difficulty of unloading the cargo.
questions.explanation: Transporting cargo that is loaded with a high center of gravity increases the risk that the transporting vehicle will tip over. Cargo should be loaded with a safe weight distribution.

questions.question: Reading a text message while driving is:
questions.answerA: Encouraged.
questions.answerB: Allowed only if you are not pulling a trailer.
questions.answerC: Illegal.
questions.explanation: Sending and reading text messages while driving is both dangerous and illegal.

questions.question: Air tank drains should:
questions.answerA: Only be used by mechanics.
questions.answerB: Only be used when it is wet outside.
questions.answerC: Be used to drain the tanks completely.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, air tank drains are used to remove water and compressor oil from the air tanks. When operating a drain, be sure to drain the tank completely.

questions.question: Scan the road ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.answerA: Two to three seconds
questions.answerB: Five to six seconds
questions.answerC: 12 to 15 seconds
questions.explanation: Good drivers scan the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of their vehicles. Looking ahead will allow you to identify and react to hazards before meeting them. Be sure to specifically look for vehicles that are coming onto the highway, entering into your lane, or turning.

questions.question: Roads are especially slippery right after it begins to rain because:
questions.answerA: The water mixes with oil and grease on the road.
questions.answerB: Tires are not made to drive in wet weather.
questions.answerC: The water yet hasn't absorbed the dirt and grease.
questions.explanation: Roads are often especially slippery when it first begins to rain. Rainwater forms a slick film when mixed with oil and grease on the road surface that has not yet washed away.

questions.question: Most heavy trucks with manual transmissions require ____ to change gears.
questions.answerA: Single clutching
questions.answerB: Double clutching
questions.answerC: Triple clutching
questions.explanation: Most heavy vehicles with manual transmissions require double clutching to shift gears. Learning to effectively change gears by double clutching takes practice.

questions.question: Skids happen when:
questions.answerA: Tires lose their grip on the road.
questions.answerB: There is too much weight in the trailer.
questions.answerC: ABS kicks in.
questions.explanation: Skids happen when tires' traction with the road surface decreases. This can be caused by over-braking, over-accelerating, over-steering, and driving too fast.

questions.question: Wheels with welding repairs are:
questions.answerA: Safe to be used if the repairs were done by a professional.
questions.answerB: Safe to be used if the repair seems solid.
questions.answerC: Not safe to be used.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use. They should be replaced before the vehicle is taken on the road.

questions.question: What is Gross Combination Weight?
questions.answerA: The total weight of the powered unit, trailer, and cargo
questions.answerB: The total weight of a single vehicle without its load
questions.answerC: The maximum weight allowed by the manufacturer
questions.explanation: Gross Combination Weight (GCW) is the total weight of a powered unit, its trailer(s), and the cargo being carried.

questions.question: If a speed limit is posted, the posted speed:
questions.answerA: Should never be exceeded.
questions.answerB: May be exceeded if passing another vehicle.
questions.answerC: May be exceeded if driving in a rural area.
questions.explanation: A maximum posted speed limit is the fastest a vehicle may travel under ideal circumstances. A driver should decrease their driving speed as conditions require. A driver should never exceed the legal speed limit.

questions.question: Improperly loaded cargo can:
questions.answerA: Look bad to other drivers.
questions.answerB: Hurt or kill the driver during a quick stop.
questions.answerC: Make it easier to stop a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Improperly secured or loaded cargo can be very dangerous. For example, loose cargo could fall in the event of a sudden stop, potentially injuring or even killing the driver.

questions.question: When starting your vehicle, the coolant temperature should:
questions.answerA: Not change.
questions.answerB: Increase gradually.
questions.answerC: Quickly jump from low to high.
questions.explanation: Watch the gauges in your vehicle before starting a trip. After starting your vehicle's engine, the coolant temperature should begin a gradual rise to the normal operating range.

questions.question: If you realize you may be running late to your destination, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up.
questions.answerB: Get upset.
questions.answerC: Deal with it and drive at a safe speed.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of developing aggressive driving behavior, you should take measures to manage your stress. One strategy to do this is to simply take a deep breath and accept your circumstances if you realize you will be late to your destination.

questions.question: If your license for your personal vehicle is suspended:
questions.answerA: You do not have to tell anyone.
questions.answerB: You must tell your employer.
questions.answerC: It will not affect your CDL.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any traffic violations while driving any vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days of the conviction. This rule excludes parking violations.

questions.question: A jogger wearing a stereo headset:
questions.answerA: Is probably aware of what is happening around them.
questions.answerB: May not be aware of what is happening around them.
questions.answerC: Can hear the sounds of traffic.
questions.explanation: Be careful around pedestrians, joggers, and cyclists who are wearing headphones. They may be unable to hear your vehicle approaching and may do dangerous things because they do not know you are there.

questions.question: Watching the road ahead of you:
questions.answerA: Allows you time to make a plan to avoid an upcoming hazard.
questions.answerB: Is not encouraged as it distracts you from driving.
questions.answerC: Is only important when traveling in congested traffic.
questions.explanation: Always watch for hazards on the road ahead. Doing this will allow you time to react to hazards before meeting them.

questions.question: When should mirrors be adjusted?
questions.answerA: Before driving
questions.answerB: While driving
questions.answerC: After driving
questions.explanation: The adjustment of your mirrors should be checked prior to the start of all trips. Adjust your mirrors as needed.

questions.question: Cargo with a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Can make a vehicle likely to tip over.
questions.answerB: Is encouraged in inclement weather.
questions.answerC: Is required on some roads.
questions.explanation: Cargo with a high center of gravity makes a vehicle more likely to tip over than cargo with a low center of gravity. For this reason, it is important that the weight of cargo be distributed as low as possible.

questions.question: When you must travel down a hill, when should you switch into a lower gear?
questions.answerA: As you begin to move downward
questions.answerB: As you go downhill and pick up speed
questions.answerC: Before you start going downhill
questions.explanation: You should always slow down and shift into a lower gear before starting down a hill. If you do not begin to drive down a hill at a low enough speed, you risk overusing your brakes, causing them to overheat and fade.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to adequately check all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: The power steering belt.
questions.answerB: The water compressor belt.
questions.answerC: The alternator belt.
questions.explanation: During the pre-trip vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to check the power steering, water pump, alternator, and air compressor belts, if the vehicle is equipped.

questions.question: In a leaf spring:
questions.answerA: Leaves should be broken.
questions.answerB: Leaves can be missing.
questions.answerC: Leaves should not be broken.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's suspension, verify that leaf springs do not have missing or broken leaves. If at least one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing, the vehicle will be put out-of-service until the defect is fixed.

questions.question: When parked on a flat surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Use wheel chocks to prevent your vehicle from moving.
questions.answerB: Not use wheel chocks.
questions.answerC: Use wheel chocks, but only if you have applied the parking brake.
questions.explanation: When parking on a level surface, you should use wheel chocks. If the vehicle is not equipped with spring brakes, this is essential to prevent the trailer from moving.

questions.question: If a worker is present in a work zone, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving at the posted speed limit.
questions.answerB: Slow to a speed under the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Drive in the grass.
questions.explanation: When driving through a work zone, follow the posted speed limits. If workers are present, you should slow to a speed that is even lower than the posted limit.

questions.question: How can you check for a leak in hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brake pedal three times, then hold down the pedal for five seconds. If the pedal moves, there may be a problem.
questions.answerB: Push the brake pedal down as far as possible and release. If the brake pedal returns to its normal position, there may be a problem.
questions.answerC: Push the brake pedal down as far as possible and release. If the brake squeaks, there may be a problem.
questions.explanation: Check hydraulic brakes by pumping the brake pedal three times before applying firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak or some other problem in the braking system.

questions.question: When stopping, the brake pedal should be:
questions.answerA: Pressed down quickly with both feet.
questions.answerB: Pressed down gradually.
questions.answerC: Lifted up quickly.
questions.explanation: When braking, push the pedal down gradually to ensure that the vehicle comes to a smooth, safe stop.

questions.question: Drivers trapped behind a slow-moving vehicle often:
questions.answerA: Follow the vehicle too closely.
questions.answerB: Allow the vehicle plenty of space.
questions.answerC: Are happy with the speed of travel.
questions.explanation: It is common for drivers to tailgate slow-moving vehicles that cannot keep up with the speed of surrounding traffic. If you are being tailgated, allow the other driver to pass your vehicle.

questions.question: Poor weight balance:
questions.answerA: Improves handling.
questions.answerB: Makes handling more difficult.
questions.answerC: Increases a driver’s ability to steer.
