questions.explanation: The controlled braking method for emergency stops involves applying the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels. Keep steering wheel movements small when braking in this way.

questions.question: What is road rage?
questions.answerA: Operating a motor vehicle with the intent of doing harm to others
questions.answerB: Operating a motor vehicle that is deemed unsafe
questions.answerC: Operating a motor vehicle that has not been inspected
questions.explanation: Aggressive driving is defined as operating a motor vehicle in a selfish, bold, or pushy manner. Road rage is defined as operating a motor vehicle with the intent of doing harm to others, or the intent of physically assaulting another driver or their vehicle.

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The hazardous materials must be listed first.
questions.answerB: The hazardous materials must be written larger.
questions.answerC: The hazardous materials must be listed in red ink.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper lists both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be entered first.

questions.question: When driving on packed snow, you should reduce your speed by:
questions.answerA: One-half or more.
questions.answerB: About one-third.
questions.answerC: About one-quarter.
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed when traveling on surfaces that provide reduced traction. Reduce your speed by one-half or more when traveling on packed snow.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.answerA: The nuts are too tight.
questions.answerB: The nuts are loose.
questions.answerC: The tires should be replaced.
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts can indicate that the nuts are loose. If you find rust near the wheel nuts, check their tightness before beginning to drive.

questions.question: When driving, you should keep in mind:
questions.answerA: The distance your vehicle will need to stop.
questions.answerB: The time you are supposed to arrive to your destination.
questions.answerC: How many cars are traveling in front of you.
questions.explanation: To drive safely, it is important to remember how much distance your vehicle will need to stop. Stopping distance for a vehicle can change with road conditions, weather conditions, and the quantity of cargo in the vehicle's tanks.

questions.question: In low temperatures, bridges usually freeze:
questions.answerA: After other parts of the roadway.
questions.answerB: Before other parts of the roadway.
questions.answerC: At the same time as other parts of the roadway.
questions.explanation: In low temperatures, bridges usually freeze before other road surfaces. When driving in cold weather, especially when weather conditions have been wet, use special caution on bridges and overpasses.

questions.question: Baffled liquid tanks are:
questions.answerA: Tanks that control the surge of liquids with perforated bulkheads.
questions.answerB: Tanks that have no bulkheads and allow liquids to move freely.
questions.answerC: Tanks that have nothing inside to slow down the flow of liquids.
questions.explanation: Baffled liquid tanks contain bulkheads with holes in them that allow the movement of liquid. This helps to inhibit the forward and backward surge of liquids. Baffled liquid tanks do not prevent side-to-side surge and may still allow rollovers.

questions.question: ____ is an example of required emergency equipment.
questions.answerA: A spare electrical fuse
questions.answerB: A loud horn
questions.answerC: A battery-operated flashlight
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: What eliminates alcohol from the bloodstream?
questions.answerA: Coffee
questions.answerB: Exercise
questions.answerC: Time
questions.explanation: The body processes alcohol at a fixed rate that cannot be sped up through tricks like drinking coffee. The only way to sober up is to give the body the time it needs to remove the alcohol on its own.

questions.question: If planning to change lanes, your mirrors should:
questions.answerA: Not be checked.
questions.answerB: Be checked as usual.
questions.answerC: Be checked more often than usual.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should be part of your normal scanning routine, be especially sure to check your mirrors when changing lanes.

questions.question: Containers of hazardous materials must be:
questions.answerA: Brightly-colored.
questions.answerB: Braced to prevent movement during transportation.
questions.answerC: Made of cardboard.
questions.explanation: Containers of hazardous materials should be braced so they will not fall, slide, or bounce around during transportation.

questions.question: How long should it take for oil pressure to reach a normal level when starting a vehicle?
questions.answerA: A few seconds
questions.answerB: About a minute
questions.answerC: About four minutes
questions.explanation: After starting a vehicle's engine, the oil pressure should come up to a normal level within seconds. Do not operate a vehicle if it has oil pressure that is low, dropping, or fluctuating.

questions.question: Placards must be placed:
questions.answerA: Within three inches of other markings.
questions.answerB: So words or numbers are read from left to right.
questions.answerC: Upside down.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards must be placed on a vehicle at least three inches away from any other markings and must positioned so that the words or numbers are level and read from left to right.

questions.question: If the brakes pull to one side or the other when used:
questions.answerA: They are working properly.
questions.answerB: They need to be checked.
questions.answerC: They will be the most effective.
questions.explanation: If the brakes pull to one side or the other when used, it is an indication of brake trouble.

questions.question: A Class 1 hazardous material is:
questions.answerA: An explosive.
questions.answerB: Liquid.
questions.answerC: Corrosive.
questions.explanation: Explosives are placed in hazardous materials Class 1.

questions.question: You can find the identification numbers assigned to hazardous chemicals:
questions.answerA: In the DOT Emergency Response Guide.
questions.answerB: In the truck's driver’s manual.
questions.answerC: On the company's website.
questions.explanation: The U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT)'s Emergency Response Guide provides information about hazardous materials, indexed by proper shipping names and hazardous materials identification numbers.

questions.question: Exhaust system parts should be:
questions.answerA: Leaking.
questions.answerB: Rubbing against other parts of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Secured tightly.
questions.explanation: When inspecting an exhaust system, you should verify that parts of the system are not loose, broken, or missing. The system's parts must be properly mounted and should not be rubbing against moving parts of the vehicle.

questions.question: When loading or unloading a tank that is divided by bulkheads, equal weight distribution is:
questions.answerA: Essential.
questions.answerB: Unimportant.
questions.answerC: Optional.
questions.explanation: Some tanks are divided into multiple smaller tanks by bulkheads. When loading or unloading such tanks, pay attention to weight distribution. Be careful not to place too much weight on a single end of the tank.

questions.question: If the letter “G” appears in Column 1 of a hazardous materials shipping paper, the shipping paper must also include:
questions.answerA: The technical name of the hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: The type of packaging containing the hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: The shipper’s phone number.
questions.explanation: A "G" in Column 1 of a hazardous materials shipping paper indicates that the description in Column 2 is the generic name for a material. A generic shipping name must be accompanied by a technical name.

questions.question: A commercial motor vehicle driver:
questions.answerA: May use any cell phone while driving.
questions.answerB: May only use a hands-free cell phone while driving, if permitted.
questions.answerC: May only use a cell phone while driving on rural roads.
questions.explanation: If you choose to use a mobile phone while operating a CMV, you may only use a hands-free mobile phone that is located close to you. However, even a hands-free mobile phone can be a dangerous distraction while driving. Make sure you are aware of all cell phone laws in the state in which you are driving.

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out when air pressure drops to a level between:
questions.answerA: 20 and 45 psi.
questions.answerB: 75 and 105 psi.
questions.answerC: 50 and 65 psi.
questions.explanation: In vehicles equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out if air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi. When the valve pops out, the protection valve will close, stopping the flow of air.

questions.question: Trailers built before ____ are not required to have spring brakes.
questions.explanation: Trailers built before 1975 are not required to have spring brakes. When parking a trailer without spring brakes, be sure to use wheel chocks to prevent the trailer from rolling.

questions.question: Hydroplaning happens most often when:
questions.answerA: A vehicle is traveling faster than 60 mph.
questions.answerB: Tire pressure is too low.
questions.answerC: Tire tread is too deep.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is most likely to occur when driving on wet roads with tire pressure that is too low and tire tread that is too worn. If there is enough water on the road, hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph.

questions.question: If you must leave the roadway and drive on the shoulder in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Brake as hard as possible.
questions.answerB: Get both sets of wheels onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Stay on the shoulder until your vehicle has stopped, if possible.
questions.explanation: If you must drive onto the shoulder to avoid a hazard, stay on it until you come to a stop; then signal, check your mirrors, and merge back into traffic. Avoid braking on the shoulder at speeds higher than about 20 mph. To help maintain control, always keep one set of wheels on the pavement, if possible.

questions.question: What is the average driver’s reaction time?
questions.answerA: 1/16 of a second
questions.answerB: 1/8 of a second
questions.answerC: 3/4 of a second
questions.explanation: The average driver has a reaction time between three-quarters of a second and one second. At 55 mph, this corresponds to a distance of 61 feet traveled.

questions.question: You may be able to identify a distracted driver by if they are:
questions.answerA: Staying within their lane.
questions.answerB: Traveling at consistent speeds.
questions.answerC: Preoccupied with using their cell phone.
questions.explanation: You may be able to tell that another driver is distracted if you can see them drifting within a lane or across lane dividers; traveling at inconsistent speeds; being preoccupied with a cell phone, a map, food, or other items; or engaging in conversation with passengers.

questions.question: If driving through flowing water or a large puddle, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Gently apply the brakes.
questions.answerC: Try to stop in the water.
questions.explanation: It is best to avoid driving through large puddles or moving water. If there is no way to avoid driving through water, you should slow down, shift into a low gear, and gently apply the brakes. Pressing linings against the brake drums or discs will keep water, mud, silt, and sand from getting inside the brake mechanisms.

questions.question: Emergency roof hatches on a bus:
questions.answerA: Must be closed before the bus is driven.
questions.answerB: Can be opened to allow for air movement during a drive.
questions.answerC: Must be removed before the bus is driven.
questions.explanation: On a bus, it is permissible to lock some emergency roof hatches in an open position to allow in fresh air. However, this should not be a regular practice.

questions.question: If being tailgated, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Increase the amount of space between your vehicle and the vehicle in front of you.
questions.answerC: Make quick movements.
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, you should increase the distance between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead of you. This reduces the need for you to make sudden changes in speed or direction while making it easier for the tailgater to pass your vehicle.

questions.question: When applying your brakes, the vehicle should:
questions.answerA: Pull to one side.
questions.answerB: Squeak.
questions.answerC: Not pull to either side.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle pulling to one side or the other while you are braking can indicate trouble with the brakes.

questions.question: People working on a disabled vehicle:
questions.answerA: Are probably aware of the roadway.
questions.answerB: May be distracted by the repair and not pay attention to the roadway.
questions.answerC: Are exempt from traffic laws.
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are working on a disabled vehicle on the side of the road. They may be focused on the repair and not paying attention to nearby traffic.

questions.question: When driving at highway speeds, you should watch the road about ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.answerA: One block
questions.answerB: 100 yards
questions.answerC: A quarter mile
questions.explanation: Stay aware of upcoming obstacles and hazards by consistently watching the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of your vehicle. When traveling at highway speeds, this is equivalent to about a quarter of a mile.

questions.question: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you should:
questions.answerA: Lock every emergency exit window.
questions.answerB: Check every railing.
questions.answerC: Remove loose handholds.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you must make sure everything is safe and in proper working condition. Take the time to ensure that each handhold and railing is securely in place and safe to be used.

questions.question: When are people usually the least alert?
questions.answerA: In the morning
questions.answerB: In the early evening
questions.answerC: Late at night
questions.explanation: Most drivers are the least alert at night, especially after midnight. Therefore, crashes due to fatigued driving are more likely at night than any other time of day.

questions.question: When driving under wet conditions, a lack of spray coming from the tires of other vehicles indicates that:
questions.answerA: Ice has formed on the road.
questions.answerB: The pavement is dry.
questions.answerC: The spray is caught on the underside of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: In wet conditions, a lack of spray coming from the tires of other vehicles indicates that ice has formed on the road. Be especially cautious when traveling under wet conditions in freezing weather.

questions.question: Aggressive driving is:
questions.answerA: Operating a vehicle in a selfish or pushy manner.
questions.answerB: Operating a vehicle with a strong regard for other motorists’ safety.
questions.answerC: Operating a vehicle in the left lane.
questions.explanation: Aggressive driving is the act of operating a motor vehicle in a selfish, bold, or pushy manner and without regard for the rights or safety of other road users.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the other driver.
questions.answerB: Assume the other driver doesn't see you.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: Whenever you pass another driver, bicyclist, or pedestrian, you should assume as a precaution that they do not see you.

questions.question: Traction is important in:
questions.answerA: Safe braking.
questions.answerB: Properly using turn signals.
questions.answerC: Operating the horn.
questions.explanation: You will not be able to brake or steer your vehicle without adequate traction. Ensure that your tires are in proper working condition before beginning a trip.

questions.question: How does doubling your speed from 20 mph to 40 mph affect your vehicle's braking distance?
questions.answerA: It stays about the same.
questions.answerB: It doubles.
questions.answerC: It quadruples.
questions.explanation: Increasing your vehicle's speed will increase your vehicle's striking power and braking distance. Doubling your vehicle's speed from 20 to 40 mph will quadruple its braking distance.

questions.question: A stopped bus:
questions.answerA: Is not a cause for concern since it is stopped.
questions.answerB: Is only a concern if passengers are exiting the bus.
questions.answerC: Is a concern whether or not passengers are visible.
questions.explanation: You should always exercise caution when driving near a stopped bus. There could be passengers in the vicinity and the bus may either prevent them from seeing you or you from seeing them.

questions.question: When slowing down, you should ____ to warn other drivers
questions.answerA: Use a turn signal
questions.answerB: Sound your horn
questions.answerC: Tap your brakes
questions.explanation: Before slowing down, it can be a good idea to lightly tap your brakes. This will cause your brake lights to flash, providing a warning to motorists behind you.

questions.question: When starting a vehicle, warning lights and buzzers:
questions.answerA: Should not light up or sound.
questions.answerB: Should turn on and shut off quickly.
questions.answerC: Should turn on and remain on.
questions.explanation: After starting a vehicle's engine, the warning lights and buzzers should turn on, then quickly turn off.

questions.question: When driving, how can you maintain alertness?
questions.answerA: Keep cool by using the air conditioner or opening a window.
questions.answerB: Eat a lot of heavy foods.
questions.answerC: Avoid stopping.
questions.explanation: Strategies to avoid becoming fatigued while driving include keeping the cab cool inside by using the air conditioner or opening a window; avoiding heavy foods; and taking rest breaks about every two hours or 100 miles.

questions.question: While passengers are on board a bus, refueling the bus in an enclosed space, allowing the bus to be towed, and conversing with the passengers are considered to be:
questions.answerA: Encouraged practices.
questions.answerB: Acceptable practices.
questions.answerC: Prohibited practices.
questions.explanation: Bus drivers should not engage in conversation with passengers, fuel a bus inside an enclosed building, or tow or push a disabled bus with riders aboard the vehicle. These are all considered to be prohibited practices.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerA: Change a tire.
questions.answerB: Explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why.
questions.answerC: Estimate the weight of a load on a trailer.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. You will need to explain what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: Passengers may not stand in front of the:
questions.answerA: Standee line.
questions.answerB: Upright line.
questions.answerC: Passenger line.
questions.explanation: On a bus designed to carry standing passengers, no passengers may stand in front of the rear of the driver's seat. Any such bus must have a line on the floor, or some other marking, that indicates where passengers may not stand. This is called a standee line.

questions.question: When making tight maneuvers, it is important for a driver to:
questions.answerA: Open their door for a better look.
questions.answerB: Use their mirrors.
questions.answerC: Flash their headlights.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should always be part of your driving routine, you should make a particular point of checking the mirrors when changing lanes, turning, merging, or making tight maneuvers.

questions.question: When driving at highway speeds, you should watch the road about ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.answerA: One block
questions.answerB: 100 yards
questions.answerC: A quarter mile
questions.explanation: Stay aware of upcoming obstacles and hazards by consistently watching the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of your vehicle. When traveling at highway speeds, this is equivalent to about a quarter of a mile.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, turning toward the driver’s side is encouraged:
questions.answerA: Because it allows the driver a better view.
questions.answerB: Because turning toward the passenger side is illegal.
questions.answerC: Because other drivers can offer assistance.
questions.explanation: If you must back up, it is safest to back toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This way, as the driver, you will have the best possible view of your path of travel.

questions.question: Stopping distance can be affected by:
questions.answerA: Driving speed.
questions.answerB: Temperature.
questions.answerC: Time of day.
questions.explanation: Factors that can affect stopping distance include the vehicle's speed, its weight, and the traction provided by the road surface.

questions.question: Broken suspension parts:
questions.answerA: Are not a cause for concern.
questions.answerB: Are extremely dangerous.
questions.answerC: Cannot be identified.
questions.explanation: The suspension system holds up a vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Defects in this system are extremely dangerous.

questions.question: To avoid a collision with a hazard on the roadway:
questions.answerA: You should always try to stop.
questions.answerB: Swerving may be a safer option than stopping.
questions.answerC: You should never swerve.
questions.explanation: Swerving out of the way of a hazard is sometimes safer than trying to stop before reaching the hazard. You can usually turn away from something more quickly than you can come to a complete stop.

questions.question: If a vehicle is equipped with power steering, the hoses should be checked:
questions.answerA: For leaks.
questions.answerB: For the proper amount of brake fluid.
questions.answerC: To ensure that they are connected to the battery.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle that is equipped with power steering, check the hoses, pumps, and fluid level. In particular, you should look for leaks in the hoses.

questions.question: Texting while driving is especially dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is both a mental and physical distraction.
questions.answerB: A message may be upsetting to the driver.
questions.answerC: People like to read and may become too engaged in their phones.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is particularly dangerous because it is both a mental and physical distraction to the driver. In addition to diverting a driver's mental attention away from the road, texting requires a person to remove at least one hand from the vehicle's controls.

questions.question: Mirrors should be:
questions.answerA: Checked only when changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Checked frequently.
questions.answerC: Checked only if there is a reason to suspect a problem.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should regularly check your mirrors, both to be aware of traffic and to check for problems on your own vehicle.

questions.question: If your vehicle is hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerA: Use the accelerator.
questions.answerB: Not use the brakes.
questions.answerC: Put the vehicle in a higher gear.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, do not apply the brakes. Instead, slow down by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch.

questions.question: When turning, you should:
questions.answerA: Signal before the turn.
questions.answerB: Turn off your turn signal just before starting the turn.
questions.answerC: Signal only if vehicles are in front of you.
questions.explanation: Be sure to activate the appropriate turn signal well in advance of a turn or lane change. Signal continuously throughout the turn and make sure to cancel the signal after the turn is completed, if your vehicle doesn't have self-canceling signals.

questions.question: Radial and bias-ply tires:
questions.answerA: Should be used together.
questions.answerB: Should be used together on the front of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Should not be used together.
questions.explanation: Radial and bias-ply tires should not be used together. All wheels on a vehicle should be the same style and equally-sized.

questions.question: A driver should:
questions.answerA: Always use turn signals when changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Only use turn signals if there is a vehicle next to them.
questions.answerC: Not use a turn signal if a lane change is obvious.
questions.explanation: Always signal before turning or changing lanes to ensure that other drivers are aware of your intentions.

questions.question: In very hot weather, tires should be checked regularly because:
questions.answerA: They may melt.
questions.answerB: Air pressure may increase with the temperature.
questions.answerC: The tread wears down more quickly than in cooler weather.
questions.explanation: Because air pressure increases with temperature, you should pay special attention to the tire mounting and pressure when traveling in hot weather.

questions.question: When checking your windshield wiper blades, the blades should be:
questions.answerA: Loose.
questions.answerB: Sticky.
questions.answerC: Secure.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check the wiper blades for damage, stiff rubber, and proper securement.

questions.question: When using a fire extinguisher to put out a fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay as far away as possible from the flames.
questions.answerB: Aim at the flames.
questions.answerC: Use any extinguisher on every type of fire.
questions.explanation: Stay as far away from a fire as possible and aim your fire extinguisher at the source or base of the fire, not at the flames. It may be appropriate to extinguish certain fires with water. If you are unsure of how to treat a specific fire, you should wait for  trained firefighters to arrive.

questions.question: If driving through flowing water or a large puddle, you should:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Gently apply the brakes.
questions.answerC: Try to stop in the water.
questions.explanation: It is best to avoid driving through large puddles or moving water. If there is no way to avoid driving through water, you should slow down, shift into a low gear, and gently apply the brakes. Pressing linings against the brake drums or discs will keep water, mud, silt, and sand from getting inside the brake mechanisms.

questions.question: When driving, knowing what is happening behind you is:
questions.answerA: Rarely important.
questions.answerB: Important.
questions.answerC: Distracting.
questions.explanation: To travel safely, it is essential that you know what is happening on all sides of your vehicle at all times. Use your mirrors frequently to help you remain aware of your surroundings.

questions.question: The tire load for a tire is stated:
questions.answerA: On the side of the tire.
questions.answerB: On the inside of the tire.
questions.answerC: On the inside of the driver’s door.
questions.explanation: The tire load, or the maximum safe weight that a tire can carry at a given pressure, is stated on the side of each tire.

questions.question: A lane change:
questions.answerA: Should be done quickly.
questions.answerB: Should be done slowly.
questions.answerC: Should be done with a jerking motion.
questions.explanation: Lane changes should be made slowly and smoothly.

questions.question: As part of a pre-trip inspection, you should look for all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Tires with too much air pressure.
questions.answerB: Tires with too much wear.
questions.answerC: Tires made by different manufacturers.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your tires, verify that there is tread depth of at least 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires and tread depth of at least 2/32 of an inch in grooves on the other tires. Be sure that your tires are not too worn, are not cracked, have proper air pressure, and are all equally sized.

questions.question: A wig wag is:
questions.answerA: A low pressure warning device.
questions.answerB: A tube that carries air to the brakes.
questions.answerC: A type of air brake system.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with air brakes are required to be equipped with a low pressure warning device. A wig wag is a type of low air pressure warning device. This device drops a mechanical arm into the driver's view if the pressure in the tanks drops to a level between 55 and 75 psi.

questions.question: The ____ are activated by an electric switch that is triggered by the brake pedal.
questions.answerA: Headlights
questions.answerB: Turn signals
questions.answerC: Brake lights
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with air brakes, the brake lights are activated when the brake pedal is pushed and air pressure moves an electric switch. With the application of air pressure, the switch will then turn on the brake lights.

questions.question: To ensure normal stopping power, drivers of vehicles equipped with a front brake limiting valve should:
questions.answerA: Set the control to normal.
questions.answerB: Set the control to the off position.
questions.answerC: Set the control to the neutral position.
questions.explanation: Some older vehicles have front brake limiting valves with "normal" and "slippery" settings. Setting a brake limiting valve to "slippery" reduces the vehicle's stopping power, so a driver should make sure the valve is in its "normal" position. Front wheel braking has proven to be effective in all driving conditions.

questions.question: Brakes out of adjustment will:
questions.answerA: Work properly.
questions.answerB: Cause some of the brakes to overwork and malfunction.
questions.answerC: Allow better acceleration.
questions.explanation: Brakes out of adjustment will fade before those that are properly adjusted. Brake adjustment must be checked frequently to help prevent brake issues.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: Is not available for vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerB: Is not helpful in most driving situations.
questions.answerC: Can help you maintain control when braking.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) are compatible with air brakes and help a driver maintain control of their vehicle by preventing wheel lockup.

questions.question: What kind of force do emergency brakes use?
questions.answerA: Air pressure
questions.answerB: Mechanical
questions.answerC: Heavy
questions.explanation: Air brakes are really three different braking systems: the service brake, the parking brake, and the emergency brake. Emergency and parking brakes are applied with mechanical force.

questions.question: An emergency brake must be controlled by:
questions.answerA: Mechanical force.
questions.answerB: Air pressure.
questions.answerC: Gravity.
questions.explanation: All trucks, truck tractors, and buses must be equipped with emergency brakes and parking brakes. Because air pressure can eventually leak away, emergency and parking brakes should be held on by mechanical force.

questions.question: If the safety relief valve in the air brake system releases air:
questions.answerA: The compressor needs more air.
questions.answerB: The air pressure has become too high.
questions.answerC: The brakes are fully operational.
questions.explanation: An air brake system has a safety relief valve, which releases air from the tanks if the pressure gets too high. If the valve must operate, something in the system is wrong and should be addressed by a mechanic.

questions.question: What do the two systems of a dual air brake system share?
questions.answerA: Hoses
questions.answerB: An air compressor
questions.answerC: Air tanks
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: Brake fade is a result of:
questions.answerA: Brakes being exposed to sunlight.
questions.answerB: Brakes being exposed to moisture.
questions.answerC: Excessive use of the brakes.
questions.explanation: If brakes are overused, they can become too hot. This overheating causes them to fade, making them less effective at slowing the vehicle.

questions.question: Brakes can get out of adjustment quickly, especially:
questions.answerA: If they are hot.
questions.answerB: In the winter time.
questions.answerC: If they are used frequently.
questions.explanation: Brakes are particularly prone to getting out of adjustment if they are hot. Be sure to routinely check the adjustment of your brakes. For a vehicle to be safely controlled, all brakes must be properly functioning and adjusted.

questions.question: Emergency brakes:
questions.answerA: Are not required on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerB: Are required only on buses.
questions.answerC: Are required on all vehicles.
questions.explanation: All trucks, truck tractors, and buses must be equipped with emergency brakes and parking brakes.

questions.question: Which of the following is not part of a vehicle’s air brake system?
questions.answerA: Air gauges
questions.answerB: Low pressure warning device
questions.answerC: Air filter
questions.explanation: Components of an air brake system include an air compressor, an air compressor governor, air storage tanks, air tank drains, an alcohol evaporator, a safety valve, a brake pedal, foundation brakes, supply pressure gauges, an application pressure gauge, a low air pressure warning signal, a stop light switch, a front brake limiting valve (on some older vehicles), spring brakes, and parking brake controls.

questions.question: A safety valve is set to open at ____ pounds per square inch (psi).
questions.explanation: The safety valve protects air tanks and the rest of an air brake system from accumulating too much air pressure. The safety valve is usually set to open at 150 psi.

questions.question: On flat surfaces, wheel chocks:
questions.answerA: Can be used to prevent a parked vehicle from moving.
questions.answerB: Make it easier for a parked vehicle to roll.
questions.answerC: Should only be used on the front driver's side tire.
questions.explanation: In situations where a driver cannot use a parking brake, wheel chocks can be used to hold a parked vehicle in place on a level surface.

questions.question: The parking brake in a newer vehicle is applied by:
questions.answerA: Moving a lever to the right.
questions.answerB: Pushing a yellow, diamond-shaped knob.
questions.answerC: Pulling a yellow, diamond-shaped knob.
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a yellow, diamond-shaped knob. The driver should pull the knob outward to apply the parking brakes and push the knob inward to release them.

questions.question: Failing to drain air tanks could result in:
questions.answerA: Water accumulations freezing and causing brake failure.
questions.answerB: Squishy brakes.
questions.answerC: Too much air collecting in the tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air tanks must be periodically drained to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. If water is not removed, it could freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.

questions.question: When parked on a flat surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Use wheel chocks to prevent your vehicle from moving.
questions.answerB: Not use wheel chocks.
questions.answerC: Use wheel chocks, but only if you have applied the parking brake.
questions.explanation: When parking on a level surface, you should use wheel chocks. If the vehicle is not equipped with spring brakes, this is essential to prevent the trailer from moving.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, what is the maximum leakage rate that is safe for a double combination vehicle?
questions.answerA: 3 psi in one minute.
questions.answerB: 6 psi in one minute.
questions.answerC: 8 psi in one minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a double combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 3 psi in one minute. If the air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: The air compressor is connected to the:
questions.answerA: Transmission.
questions.answerB: Engine.
questions.answerC: Radiator.
questions.explanation: The air compressor of an air brake system is connected to the engine through gears or a v-belt. The compressor may be air-cooled or cooled by the engine cooling system.

questions.question: If you are braking on dry pavement while traveling at 55 mph, how much distance will brake lag add to your overall stopping distance?
questions.answerA: 32 feet
questions.answerB: 45 feet
questions.answerC: 20 feet
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to the vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: What do air brakes use to make the brakes work?
questions.answerA: Compressed air
questions.answerB: Outside air
questions.answerC: Non-compressed air
questions.explanation: Many large CMVs are equipped with air brakes. An air braking system uses compressed air to operate.

questions.question: Vehicles equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have ____ malfunction lamps to indicate when the ABS is not working.
questions.answerA: Green
questions.answerB: Blue
questions.answerC: Yellow
questions.explanation: Vehicles with ABS have yellow malfunction lamps to alert drivers when the braking systems are not working. Be sure you know where the malfunction lamp on your vehicle is before beginning a trip.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal:
questions.answerA: Is not recommended on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerB: Is required on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerC: Is optional on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.explanation: Any vehicle with air brakes must be equipped with a low air pressure warning signal.

questions.question: Why do large vehicles use air brakes?
questions.answerA: Other brake systems squeak too loudly.
questions.answerB: Air brakes are very effective systems.
questions.answerC: Other braking systems are hard to come by.
questions.explanation: If used and maintained properly, air brakes are a safe and effective way to stop large, heavy vehicles.

questions.question: Braking mechanisms are located inside:
questions.answerA: The fifth wheel.
questions.answerB: A brake drum.
questions.answerC: The landing gear.
questions.explanation: Drum brakes are attached to the wheels and located on the axles of a vehicle. The braking mechanisms that cause the vehicle to stop can be found inside of a drum brake.

questions.question: What is brake lag?
questions.answerA: The time required for the brakes to work after the brake pedal is pressed
questions.answerB: The distance between the brake pedal and the floor
questions.answerC: The amount of air pressure used to stop the vehicle
questions.explanation: Because air takes time to flow through the air lines to the brakes, air brakes cannot begin working instantly. There is often a brake lag of at least one-half of a second between the moment the brake pedal is pressed and the moment the brakes begin to work.

questions.question: When you are about to start down a hill, you should switch into a ____ gear.
questions.answerA: Higher
questions.answerB: Faster
questions.answerC: Lower
questions.explanation: Before starting down a hill, be sure to switch into a low gear. Gravity will increase your vehicle's speed as you travel downhill.

questions.question: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on in a vehicle with air brakes, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Test the brakes while driving, but continue driving if nothing seems wrong.
questions.answerB: Immediately stop driving.
questions.answerC: Drive with the hazard lights activated.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on while you are operating a vehicle with air brakes, you should stop and safely park the vehicle as soon as possible. It is essential that you are able to stop safely while you still have some braking power remaining.

questions.question: To make a stop in a vehicle equipped with air brakes, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Press the brake pedal down.
questions.answerB: Lift the brake pedal up.
questions.answerC: Pull out the air brake knob.
questions.explanation: To make a normal stop in a vehicle that is equipped with air brakes, you should simply press the brake pedal down.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Air tanks are shared between both systems.
questions.answerB: Each system has its own air tanks.
questions.answerC: You must designate which system you are using.
questions.explanation: There are two air brake systems in a dual air brake system. The systems share a set of brake controls, but each system has its own tanks, hoses, and lines.

questions.question: What color light indicates a vehicle's ABS is not working?
questions.answerA: Green
questions.answerB: Blue
questions.answerC: Yellow
questions.explanation: On vehicles with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS), yellow malfunction lamps alert the driver to ABS malfunction.

questions.question: The rods in S-cam brakes move the slack adjusters when air pressure is added to the brake chambers. This air pressure is added to the chambers when the driver:
questions.answerA: Presses the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Uses the emergency brake.
questions.answerC: Uses the trailer hand valve.
questions.explanation: When pressing the brake pedal in a vehicle with S-cam brakes, air will enter the brake chambers. The added air pressure will push out the rods and move slack adjusters, twisting the brake camshafts.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.answerA: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS).
questions.answerB: Bluetooth.
questions.answerC: A GPS.
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997, and other vehicles with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1998, must be equipped with anti-lock brakes.

questions.question: What does an air compressor do in an air brake system?
questions.answerA: It pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: It fills the tires.
questions.answerC: It moves air to the back of the truck.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks. The air compressor is controlled by the air compressor governor.

questions.question: The two markings on a front brake limiting valve usually read:
questions.answerA: "Normal" and "slippery."
questions.answerB: "Low" and "high."
questions.answerC: "Left" and "right."
questions.explanation: Some vehicles with air brake systems manufactured before 1975 have a front brake limiting valve with "normal" and "slippery" settings.

questions.question: Air tank drains should:
questions.answerA: Not be used by the driver.
questions.answerB: Only be used when it is wet outside.
questions.answerC: Be used to drain the tanks completely.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS):
questions.answerA: Reduce a vehicle's normal braking capacity.
questions.answerB: Are in addition to other braking systems and do not reduce a vehicle's braking power.
questions.answerC: Are not effective on larger vehicles.
questions.explanation: If equipped, ABS is in addition to a vehicle's normal braking system and does not increase or decrease the braking power of any other system. ABS only activates when a vehicle's wheels are about to lock.

questions.question: Vehicles equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have ____ malfunction lamps to indicate when the ABS is not working.
questions.answerA: Green
questions.answerB: Blue
questions.answerC: Yellow
questions.explanation: Vehicles with ABS have yellow malfunction lamps to alert drivers when the braking systems are not working. Be sure you know where the malfunction lamp on your vehicle is before beginning a trip.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal:
questions.answerA: Is not recommended on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerB: Is required on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerC: Is optional on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.explanation: Any vehicle with air brakes must be equipped with a low air pressure warning signal.

questions.question: If air pressure drops to a level between ____, a visual low pressure warning signal should have already activated.
questions.answerA: 55 and 75 psi.
questions.answerB: 80 and 95 psi.
questions.answerC: 65 and 100 psi.
questions.explanation: A visual low pressure warning signal should activate before air pressure drops to a level between 55 and 75 psi. This signal could be a light, a buzzer, or a wig wag.

questions.question: An alcohol evaporator is especially important:
questions.answerA: In cold weather.
questions.answerB: In hot weather.
questions.answerC: In dry weather.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems contain an alcohol evaporator. This evaporator introduces alcohol into the system to help prevent ice from forming in cold weather.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual air brakes, a leak in one system ____ the second system.
questions.answerA: Will always affect
questions.answerB: May not affect
questions.answerC: Is caused by
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. If there is an air leak in one system, it may not affect the other.

questions.question: What do air brakes use to make the brakes work?
questions.answerA: Compressed air
questions.answerB: Outside air
questions.answerC: Non-compressed air
questions.explanation: Many large CMVs are equipped with air brakes. An air braking system uses compressed air to operate.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Should not be used in cold weather.
questions.answerB: Are helpful to remove water and oil from the air tanks.
questions.answerC: Are used to move air to the brakes.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually has a certain amount of water and oil in it. This can harm the system if allowed to accumulate. Air tanks have drain valves to aid in removing water and oil from the compressed air.

questions.question: Failing to drain air tanks could result in:
questions.answerA: Water accumulations freezing and causing brake failure.
questions.answerB: Squishy brakes.
questions.answerC: Too much air collecting in the tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air tanks must be periodically drained to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. If water is not removed, it could freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are on, you should:
questions.answerA: Not use the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Press the accelerator.
questions.answerC: Move the steering wheel.
questions.explanation: Do not use the brake pedal when the spring brakes are on. This could damage the brakes by subjecting them to the combined forces of springs and air pressure.

questions.question: When experiencing cold weather, be sure to check your vehicle's alcohol evaporator:
questions.answerA: Every three hours.
questions.answerB: Every day.
questions.answerC: Every other week.
questions.explanation: An alcohol evaporator can help prevent ice from building up in an air brake system. In cold weather, the evaporator should be checked and refilled every day.

questions.question: You should ____ if the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving.
questions.answerA: Stop where you are and park
questions.answerB: Exit the roadway as soon as safely possible
questions.answerC: Continue driving normally
questions.explanation: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, it is important that you safely exit the roadway as soon as possible and park your vehicle. If the air pressure gets too low, the brakes will no longer work well enough for you to stop safely.

questions.question: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving, but have the brakes repaired within a week.
questions.answerB: Pull over and inspect the brakes.
questions.answerC: Phone a mechanic while driving.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on while you are driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should immediately bring the vehicle to a safe stop while you are still able to control the brakes. Inspect and repair the brakes as soon as possible.

questions.question: What is the tractor protection valve?
questions.answerA: A valve that keeps air in the brake system should a bad leak occur
questions.answerB: A valve that prevents the trailer from being accidentally released
questions.answerC: A valve that prevents the vehicle from going too fast
questions.explanation: A tractor protection valve keeps air in a tractor or truck air brake system should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak. The valve will close automatically if the pressure drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerA: To test the trailer brakes.
questions.answerB: To check the connection between the trailer and tractor.
questions.answerC: To accelerate.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve (also referred to as the "trolley valve" or "Johnson bar") works the trailer brakes and should be used only when testing them. Using the trailer hand valve while driving could result in a skid.

questions.question: If you are backing and the trailer begins to drift off-course, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Return the steering wheel to the 12 o’clock position.
questions.answerB: Turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction of the drift.
questions.answerC: Turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the drift.
questions.explanation: If your trailer begins to drift while you are backing, you should correct the drift immediately by turning the top of the steering wheel in the direction of the drift.

questions.question: The tractor protection valve:
questions.answerA: Ensures that oil adequately lubricates the engine.
questions.answerB: Protects the tractor from exceeding a set speed.
questions.answerC: Keeps air in the truck braking system if the trailer develops a leak.
questions.explanation: A tractor protection valve keeps air in a tractor or truck air brake system should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak. The valve will close automatically if the pressure drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: When driving while pulling trailers, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sudden turns with the steering wheel.
questions.answerB: Avoid making sudden moves.
questions.answerC: Push the accelerator to the floor when starting from a stop.
questions.explanation: You should always steer gently and smoothly while pulling a trailer. Making sudden steering moves could cause the trailer to tip over.

questions.question: Fully-loaded rigs:
questions.answerA: Are less likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerB: Are more likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerC: Are just as likely to roll over as empty rigs.
questions.explanation: Fully-loaded rigs are more vulnerable to rolling over than empty rigs because the weight of the cargo gives the vehicles higher centers of gravity.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve:
questions.answerA: Should always be used for parking.
questions.answerB: Should only be used for parking on a downgrade.
questions.answerC: Should never be used for parking.
questions.explanation: Never use the trailer hand valve while parking because doing so may release the air pressure  from the braking system, releasing the brakes that are holding the vehicle in place. Instead, use the parking brake or wheel chocks.

questions.question: If you are backing and become unsure about your path of travel, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue backing.
questions.answerB: Stop and get out to look.
questions.answerC: Continue backing, but more slowly than before.
questions.explanation: If you are unsure of your path while you are driving in reverse, you should stop, exit the vehicle, and recheck your path of travel.

questions.question: To prevent a rollover, cargo should be:
questions.answerA: Loaded with most weight on the driver’s side of the trailer.
questions.answerB: Placed near the rear of the trailer.
questions.answerC: Spread out in the trailer.
questions.explanation: Cargo weight should be evenly distributed within a trailer to reduce the risk of a rollover. Do not place too much weight on one side of a trailer.

questions.question: Combination vehicles:
questions.answerA: Often have taller trailers than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerB: Are usually lighter than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerC: Require more skill to drive than single commercial vehicles.
questions.explanation: Driving combination vehicles requires more skill than driving single commercial vehicles. Combinations are generally longer, generally heavier, and are more vulnerable to rollover.

questions.question: Before beginning a trip, you should:
questions.answerA: Leave the service line valve open.
questions.answerB: Remove the relay valves.
questions.answerC: Close the emergency line valve.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should ensure that air reaches all air brakes on all trailers by opening up the rear emergency line and service line shut-off valves and listening for escaping air. Close both shut-off valves before beginning to drive.

questions.question: Combination vehicles need extra space on the road because they:
questions.answerA: Drive more slowly than other commercial motor vehicles.
questions.answerB: Are heavier than other commercial motor vehicles.
questions.answerC: Need more space to turn and stop than other commercial motor vehicles.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles need more space on the road than other commercial vehicles because they are longer and need more space to turn and stop. It is especially important to properly manage space when you are operating a combination vehicle.

questions.question: When glad hands are coupled, the seals should be pressed together at a ____ angle.
questions.answerA: 50-degree
questions.answerB: 180-degree
questions.answerC: 90-degree
questions.explanation: When coupling, be sure to couple the proper glad hands. When glad hands are connected, the seals should be pressed together at a 90-degree angle.

questions.question: When backing a trailer, you must first turn the steering wheel:
questions.answerA: In the direction you want the trailer to go.
questions.answerB: In the direction opposite of where you want the trailer to go.
questions.answerC: To the left.
questions.explanation: When backing a vehicle without a trailer, a driver must turn the vehicle in the direction that they want to go. However, when backing with a trailer, the driver must begin by turning in the opposite direction. Once the trailer starts to turn, they should turn the wheel in the other direction to follow the trailer.

questions.question: When coupling:
questions.answerA: You can assume all vehicles are the same.
questions.answerB: Be sure that you are coupling correctly.
questions.answerC: Cracks in the mounting are acceptable.
questions.explanation: Incorrect coupling and uncoupling of combination vehicles can have extremely dangerous consequences.

questions.question: When a combination vehicle goes around a corner:
questions.answerA: The vehicle must use at least two lanes.
questions.answerB: The front and rear wheels will move in different paths.
questions.answerC: It is best to allow the rear wheels to drive over the curb.
questions.explanation: When a vehicle goes around a corner, the rear wheels follow a different path than the front wheels. This is called off-tracking. This effect is especially pronounced on vehicles with trailers.

questions.question: If color-coded, which color is used to identify service lines?
questions.answerA: White
questions.answerB: Yellow
questions.answerC: Blue
questions.explanation: Air lines are sometimes color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes when coupling glad hands. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: Older trailers are not equipped with spring brakes. This means that if the air supply for a vehicle's air braking system leaks away:
questions.answerA: The trailer will stop normally.
questions.answerB: The trailer will not have brakes.
questions.answerC: The trailer will speed up.
questions.explanation: Older trailers do not have spring brakes. This means that if the air supply in an older trailer's air tank has leaked away, there will be no working brakes connected to the trailer and its wheels will turn freely.

questions.question: What is the Johnson bar?
questions.answerA: A hand valve that works the trailer brakes
questions.answerB: A valve that indicates the fuel level
questions.answerC: A valve that limits the amount of cargo
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve, also called the trolley valve or Johnson bar, is used to work the trailer brakes. It should be used only to test the brakes. Using it while a vehicle is in motion could cause a skid.

questions.question: If color-coded, which color is used to identify emergency, or supply, lines?
questions.answerA: White
questions.answerB: Yellow
questions.answerC: Red
questions.explanation: Air lines are sometimes color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes when coupling glad hands. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: Trailers built before ____ are not required to have spring brakes.
questions.explanation: Trailers built before 1975 are not required to have spring brakes. When parking a trailer without spring brakes, be sure to use wheel chocks to prevent the trailer from rolling.

questions.question: If unsure if a trailer has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can:
questions.answerA: Look under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.answerC: Assume it does have ABS.
questions.explanation: If you do not know whether or not a trailer is equipped with ABS, look under the vehicle for the electronic control unit and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: When you are pulling a trailer, the air supply control lever should be in its ____ position.
questions.answerA: Emergency
questions.answerB: Supply
questions.answerC: Normal
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "normal" position, it is properly set for you to pull a trailer.

questions.question: Fully-loaded rigs:
questions.answerA: Usually are very responsive to steering.
questions.answerB: Are more likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerC: Can stop quickly.
questions.explanation: Fully-loaded rigs are more vulnerable to rolling over than empty rigs because the weight of the cargo gives the vehicles higher centers of gravity.

questions.question: Rearward amplification refers to:
questions.answerA: The amount of noise projected to the rear of a vehicle.
questions.answerB: The cause of the "crack-the-whip" effect.
questions.answerC: The number of trailers that can be pulled by a tractor.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with trailers are vulnerable to rollover due to the "crack-the-whip" effect, which is caused by rearward amplification.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), brakes should be applied:
questions.answerA: In the same way as they would be in a vehicle without ABS.
questions.answerB: As the vehicle is placed in neutral.
questions.answerC: With the hand brake.
questions.explanation: When driving a vehicle with ABS, you should brake in the same manner as you would in a vehicle without ABS.

questions.question: When driving with trailers, you should:
questions.answerA: Make quick, sudden changes.
questions.answerB: Avoid making sudden moves.
questions.answerC: Accelerate by pushing the accelerator to the floor.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of tipping over when driving with a trailer, you should steer gently and smoothly. Avoid making sudden movements.

questions.question: Keeping cargo centered on a rig can:
questions.answerA: Help you drive faster.
questions.answerB: Prevent a rollover.
questions.answerC: Make turns more dangerous.
questions.explanation: A rollover is more likely if cargo is unevenly loaded in a rig. To help prevent a dangerous rollover, it is important to keep a load as centered on the rig as possible.

questions.question: If a parked trailer does not have spring brakes, you should keep the trailer from moving by:
questions.answerA: Having the vehicle parked against a wall or other vehicle.
questions.answerB: Using chock blocks.
questions.answerC: Parking on a slight incline.
questions.explanation: If a parked trailer does not have spring brakes, wheel chocks should be used to prevent it from moving.

questions.question: Combination vehicles are usually:
questions.answerA: Easier to drive than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerB: Lighter than single commercial vehicles.
questions.answerC: More difficult to drive than single commercial vehicles.
questions.explanation: Driving combination vehicles requires more skill than driving single commercial vehicles. Combinations are generally longer, generally heavier, and are more vulnerable to rollover.

questions.question: The tractor protection valve:
questions.answerA: Ensures that oil adequately lubricates the engine.
questions.answerB: Protects the tractor from exceeding a set speed.
questions.answerC: Keeps air in the truck braking system if the trailer develops a leak.
questions.explanation: A tractor protection valve keeps air in a tractor or truck air brake system should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak. The valve will close automatically if the pressure drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: When driving while pulling trailers, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sudden turns with the steering wheel.
questions.answerB: Avoid making sudden moves.
questions.answerC: Push the accelerator to the floor when starting from a stop.
questions.explanation: You should always steer gently and smoothly while pulling a trailer. Making sudden steering moves could cause the trailer to tip over.

questions.question: The best way to recognize that your trailer has started to skid is by:
questions.answerA: Seeing other drivers' faces.
questions.answerB: Checking the trailer in your mirrors.
questions.answerC: Feeling the trailer move.
questions.explanation: The easiest way to become aware that your trailer has begun to jackknife is to observe it in your mirrors. Checking your trailer in your mirrors will also allow you to spot any skidding at the earliest possible moment.

questions.question: If you must cross traffic while driving a combination vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume other drivers will make room for your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Wait for a gap large enough for your vehicle to safely cross.
questions.answerC: Rely only on your mirrors.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles require more space on the road than other vehicles. When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that there is a large enonugh gap in traffic to safely do so.

questions.question: The emergency air line supplies air to the:
questions.answerA: Relay valves.
questions.answerB: Trailer air tanks.
questions.answerC: Signal line.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line (also known as the supply line) has two functions. The first is to supply air to the trailer air tanks, and the second is to control the emergency brakes on combination vehicles.

questions.question: When testing ____, you should apply your vehicle's brakes with the hand control while moving the vehicle forward slowly.
questions.answerA: The Anti-Lock Braking System
questions.answerB: The emergency braking system
questions.answerC: The trailer service brakes
questions.explanation: To test the trailer service brakes, you should first ensure that the braking system has a normal air pressure level, then release the parking brake. You should then move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control. If the trailer service brakes are working properly, you will feel the brakes activate.

questions.question: The ____ trailer is the most likely to turn over if a driver takes a turn too quickly.
questions.answerA: Front
questions.answerB: Last
questions.answerC: Middle
questions.explanation: When making a turn, be sure to steer gently and smoothly. Making a quick turn while pulling trailers is dangerous and can increase the risk of the last trailer rolling over.

questions.question: When coupling, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure to couple the proper glad hands.
questions.answerB: Only couple one set of glad hands.
questions.answerC: It is best to leave one glad hand loose.
questions.explanation: When coupling air brake hoses, you should make sure the proper pairs of gland hands are connected. They are sometimes color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.answerA: In the direction you want the trailer to go.
questions.answerB: In the direction opposite of where you want the trailer to go.
questions.answerC: To the left.
questions.explanation: When backing a vehicle without a trailer, a driver must turn the vehicle in the direction that they want to go. However, when backing with a trailer, the driver must begin by turning in the opposite direction. Once the trailer starts to turn, they should turn the wheel in the other direction to follow the trailer.
